content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												One of the most fun game i played in years. Hand drawn graphics are beautiful, the music is amazing and the mecanics...this is not about reflex like every other platformer but more about thinking it through. You basically can't die, just rewind or fast-forward time like a boss. Each world incorporates new mechanics like a clone of yourself and stuff. Some of the puzzles are insanely difficult but so rewarding when accomplished. There are stars to collect but i did't get what was that all about because it doesnt unlock anything except a  constellation at the start of the game. Finishing the game unlocks the speedrun mode, which is pretty hard. And if you want your last achievement you have to complete the game in under 45 minutes...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2012
												So what do you get when you combine something only understood by those who analyze Shakespear for hours and time travel? Something like Braid.Braid's best feature is the awesome power of going back in time if you mess something up. What isn't mentioned is what this entitles as well. Going back in time at twice the speed allows you to beat objects unneffected by time travel to their destination, small gold rings create black holes in which time travels at a near stop, and creating copies of yourself by doing something you would do normally and then traveling back in time to do something else. Each world has its own unique time power (even the last) that the game gives only subtle hints about and I went bonkers (in a good way) having to figure that out for myself. That said, the game's short and will probably be finished within three hours if you're looking for all the puzzle pieces. GOOD LUCK WITH THAT. A beautiful game to witness and hear, yet still fun to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												It's rather daunting to speak about a legend like Braid. Many credit it as the reason the indie game Renaissance kicked off in the first place, and whether you believe that's a fair read or overreaching a bit, there's no question that Braid played a formidable role in the advancement of the indie game market, and the role of indie game as "art film," not "demo album." Braid succeeded financially and critically. Braid opened people's eyes to the idea of the indie game as a form of expression, and the validity, and necessity, of games that don't follow a formula or sort neatly into a category. To call Braid merely a "platformer" is to miss the point entirely.Most of what I'd like to say about Braid falls under the realm of spoilers -- it's a very hard game to talk about, without not only entering spoiler territory, but asserting one's own theories about what happens in it, what the player is seeing, what the events depicted in the game really mean. Braid is a game to be interpreted, to be meditated upon...not a game to be engaged with blind forward momentum. Speedrunning through Braid would be a terrible waste of the experience, at least until the game's events are well known to the player. Let me try to delicately walk the line of preserving Braid's many secrets, while sharing enough of the game to help demonstrate why it shines.From a mechanical perspective, Braid is a sidescrolling platformer. Your protagonist Tim runs, climbs, jumps and falls in a manner immediately familiar to the player. Upon his first death, however, we learn that we have the power to reverse time, and by holding down a key, rewind the game back to the point of decision and try again. We can do this as often as we like, reverse every mistake made, every mistimed jump, every unsuccessful stab at a puzzle, if we wish. Indeed, the game makes clear that this is not only our power as player, but Tim's own power, and that he's done this, over and over, in his own life. The puzzles encountered begin to incorporate Tim's power, requiring one to play with the flow of time to solve them, at this point.The puzzles are clever and fun, and finally figuring them out is quite rewarding, but they are, like the puzzles of Thomas Was Alone, merely a macguffin to draw the player into Tim's world, into his head, and into his way of thinking. The game is a philosophical reflection upon what it means to be Tim, to have this power, and to look at the world the way he does. Braid engaged by its mechanics is a clever and interesting experience, but Braid engaged in the context of its meaning, of what it might be saying "between the lines" -- that's what makes it a must-have game. Enter Braid with the idea that the game is just an excuse to have a very interesting conversation with its creator about human agency, mistakes, regret, and the nature of interpersonal relationships. Be ready for the game to throw you some ferocious curveballs, and for you not to be satisfied with its story as a story in itself -- rather, for the story to be a vehicle that brings you to a new vantage point, from which to examine your own ideas of human agency, cause, effect, and meaning.Braid left me with a head full of thoughts about the way memory fails us, and the places in which wishful thinking seeps into the jars of our memories we thought were watertight, and spoils the things we imagined were well-preserved forever. It asks us, at the beginning, to imagine a world in which forgiveness is absolute, where mistakes can be erased, leaving no mark upon the future. Trial with ever-mitigatable, never lasting error sounds lovely...but the game will, eventually, force you to confront the consequences of such a world, and to the temptation to mistake uncomfortable truths and reality for "mistakes." Surprising narrative power, for a cartoonish platformer with liberal nods back to the Super Mario Brothers franchise. If you're looking for a clever platform-puzzle game, Braid will fit the bill...but you'll be missing so much of what makes it special to engage it simply as a platform-puzzle game. Braid is a story, an inner journey, into the meaning of human agency, of love, loss, mistakes, lessons learned, and the nature of why time and causality work the way they do, told through a deceptively simple run-and-jump game with unlimited continues. If you're the sort who wants the game to applaud and cheer you for winning, you're exactly the sort of person Braid wants to meet...but you're going to be disappointed, in the end. That's okay. Weather the disappointment. Braid is talking to you; let it speak. Embrace your own discomfort with the things Braid has to say. Listen, and stop rewinding time to see if it'll say what you want to hear. Its message is not a "mistake" to be "fixed."

content:
Posted: July 6, 2011
												Braid. When you first look at this platform game, you think it's another Super Mario spin off that looks like it was hand painted. That is until you actually play Braid. I was taken away right off the start by the music, which sounded like from India. It really made me feel like I was in another world. Then the game play.  I struggled on certian levels and became frustrated to the point I peeked on Youtube for help. When I saw the solution, I said, "What the heck? This game is twisted." Best description of this game is an "Enjoyable Fever Dream." This game is beyond Alice in Wonderland. Read the critics reviews and the list is long. The game is that good! If you have read this far and dont have Braid. You will get this game. Not just from my recommendation. But for the fact this classic game should not be passed. A gem of a game :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												This is one of those artsy indie games. Also one of the first larger successes in the "public" indie scene.The game itself it a platform puzzle game with elements or references from games like Mario and homages to several other "old school" NES games.There also is a very interesting mechanic that is important to the core of the gameplay; Rewinding time.This little feature will prove more important than a simple "save point"-feature in games such as Prince of Persia: SoT. In Braid certain elements are unchained from the time/space continuum - In other words, you can rewind time and unchained elements will stay put, or if you are holding them; Follow you back to where you were.This entire process is used cleverly in the puzzles you are faced with.Apart from the puzzles there is a very neat story tucked into the game(as with most artsy indie titles).Without getting into too much detail on that part; It reminds me of a very well known "Save the captured Princess" scenario... With a twist.I'm not going to spoil it and I'll leave it up to you to figure out the rest.It's a short but great game - clocking at around 5-6 hours to beat it.For what it is, it's well worth the time spent.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Over rated and convoluted.Much of this game's praise seems to stem from is setting and story rather than mechanics, but I found it to be the other way around.Keeping it short...The time-reversal based puzzles were impeccably creative. They were fun, mostly fair challenges to navigate.The story's attempt to be deep ends up being head-scratchingly vague with many nonsequential nuggets of it delivered throughout. Having time manipulation as your game's theme isn't much of an excuse for just mashing a myriad of vagueries together and expecting people to find it deep and brooding (which apparently lots did.)Even after looking up a detailed story/ending synopsis, the ultimate "true ending" is hardly tantamount to the work it requires to puzzle it out.I bought this game expecting a short and sweet but heavily impactful emotional trip like the amazing "Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons", but was left with just a quaint, fun little indie platformer. Would reccomend if on sale for a buck or three. Excellent soundtrack.

												Here is a game that will challenge your brain mercilessly with its brilliantly made puzzles, but unlike other puzzle games, the challanges do not come from trying to decipher the designers mind or making complex mental gymnastics, they come from understanding the simple but unique laws of physics that govern each of the games worlds and manipulating them accordingly, once your mind is in tune with the game, the solutions to the puzzles come as second nature, just like in Portal.It will also make a lasting impression with its complex metaphors, beautiful visuals and one of the best soundtracks in gaming.Braid is a work of beauty.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Great platforming puzzler.Braid is one of a few games that rose during the 'indie craze' next to games like Super meat boy, Bastion and Binding of Issac.Story is deep. I was surprised that a puzzle game could have such a good story. You play as Tim, an individual who is looking for a princess who has unfortunately been captured by a monster. It's not a plot which openly tells you what is going on per se, rather there is quite a bit of ambiguity (especially the ending which is good), which leaves the player to reflect on what is actually going on. Many themes play out in the story including desire, regret and making up for mistakes. Gameplay is great, burrowing elements from Mario. Each stage pits you on one end of the map, trying to reach the end on the other side. Stages are unique, with different puzzles and goals to reach in order to pass, such simply reaching the end, eliminate all foes, using keys to open doors etc. Similar to stars in Mario, each level has a selected amount of puzzle pieces to collect. Each, piece collected helps to complete a picture which provides some incites to the story. There are platforms you can reach by jumping on them. You can also defeat foes by jumping on them and avoid traps by jumping over them. The only enemies are giant head things which walk around and may jump to different platforms (which reminds me of Gumpas). There are also traps such as pitfalls, spikes and canons.  You only have 1 life, so a single collision between a 'Gumpa' or trap will kill you instantly.  Fortunately, death doesn't end the game, instead this is the part where you make the most of your 'Time control' power. Reminiscent of 'POP Sands of time', you have the ability to reverse the flow of time, sending Tim back before his current predicament. Besides using it to save your life you can also use it to solve puzzles, by stopping time to allow  you to think of a plan or moving back objects to obtain items. Some puzzles may leave some guessing and frustrated, however with some patience they can be solved easily (or just use a guide).Soundtrack is amazing. The music is very calm, with sorta 'Irish tune to it', and something you can listen to calm yourself (which especially helps with some of the puzzles). Sound effects are also good. there is no voice acting in the game, with the story told through text.Graphics are excellent. The 2D-art style is vibrant and detailed. It is quite attractive and fits perfectly for the game.Besides the main campaign, there is also 'speed-run' mode which is unlocked  after beating the game. The mode tests how fast you can get through certain stages in the game.If your looking for a good story and don't mind some platforming and puzzles, Braid will show you how brilliance can be formed in a simple indie game.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2012
												Both heartfelt and cerebral, a solid platformer as well as a very sharp and entirely self-aware deconstruction of platforming as a genre. People throw deconstruction around as a cheap buzz word, but here it actually applies. "Braid" quite literally and systematically disassembles the most common and basic mechanics of the past 30 years of platformers and both isolates and reassembles them in new ways on a level by level basis--all leading up to its brilliant twist ending which turns the conventional narrative of the genre completely on its head. Plus, it's one of very few games which use "game mechanics" and "gameplay" as languages and means of expression in their own right. You can learn as much of the philosophical nature of time and paradox just from playing Braid as you could from an entire undergrad course on the topics, not to mention about more ephemeral topics such as the nature of love, obsession, and regret.Pretentious? Maybe. But luckily it's also fun to play as well.

I'll never forget the frustration we felt as an entire room full of teenagers struggled to get some of the game's trickier puzzle pieces, or the cheers that went up when a puzzle was finally untangled, or the audible gasps elicited by the game's final level. Part of me was worried that buying the game now, seven years later, and playing it would dull some of those memories. I was worried it wouldn't be as good as I remembered. But to my relief, it's just as difficult and rewarding and strange as I remembered. content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												At this point it really isn’t news that if you like indie puzzle games you should play Braid. This game is part of the canon—and for very good reason. Braid is a beautiful piece of craftsmanship.The core engine of Braid is a simple, 2D platformer reminiscent of Mario. (The resemblance to classic Mario is more than passing, and the creators of Braid overtly nod to it at several points.) But to the simple mechanics of jumping and dodging Braid has added a novel element: the ability to reverse time. At the touch of a button you can rewind your performance of a stage to whatever point you like and then begin again from that point.That alone would be novel, but not worth much—just an alternative to replaying levels—but Braid makes this mechanic the central tool in the solution of an array of tricky puzzles. At first your control of time is just a way of undoing mistakes, but it quickly takes on other dimensions as you, for example, discover items which are immune to your powers and so keep moving normally while all else rewinds. Solutions to the problems Braid poses are not usually a matter of muddling through, trying things until something works, but instead involve having some insight about the central mechanic and how it affects your surroundings. Like a good riddle there is a moment of dawning insight and suddenly you see things in a new way.And the surroundings are themselves wonderful. While the mechanics of the game would be worthy regardless (an early version of Braid won a game design award while the graphics were still just place holders) the graphics makes the game into a piece of visual art. Everything in Braid looks hand-made in the best possible sense. The levels have an almost water colored look. And while there are actually fairly few sprites in the game, corresponding to the small number of pieces out of which levels are constructed, the background elements are various and gorgeous. Each group of puzzles has a distinct aesthetic subtly adapted to the content of the gameplay. Beautiful, low key instrumental music compliments all this perfectly. This game is simply pretty, and in a way that makes playing it feel meditative.The story, provided mostly by textual interludes, is rather impressionistic. I found it difficult to make sense of, and in the end not entirely satisfying. But nonetheless thematic elements intertwine with the gameplay. The most obvious example is that you play as a man troubled by regrets, and this theme of regret resonates in the mechanic of undoing actions you have already performed.Braid is a piece of art, pure and simple, but as already mentioned it is also a tightly designed puzzle game. This means some stages are rather challenging, as they should be. However, a nice feature is that the puzzles are not locked into strict sequence. If the needed insight simply will not come in one place then it is open to the player to skip ahead and return for the missing bits much later, lessening the potential frustration that’s part of puzzle games.Braid has taken simple parts, things that have been around since 8-bit consoles, and polished them until they shone. Play it. You’ll be glad you did.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												A wonderful, clever game.  It will bend your mind in some new ways.  I am used to most puzzle games requiring you to be observant, and fluent with their tools to figure out 90% of the puzzles.  This is not one of them.  The game centers around a man struggling with regret over some past mistake chasing after a mysterious princess.  However, the man is no ordinary man, he can control time (forwards and backwards).  So unlike many platformer games, death isn't usually the obstacle.  Yes, there are some parts that require good jumping skills, but with the ability to rewind time there is little frustration.  All of the difficulty is in figuring out how to collect all of the puzzle pieces of the paintings.  This is the main objective beside finding the princess.  Many puzzle pieces simply require careful planning and proper use of time control, but some will certainly make you say "I never thought of that!" (far more than 10%).  The levels have a painted appearance and are quite gorgeous to look at.  They change up the in-level elements to keep you on your toes, but I did find that there is little environmental shift (at least between the first and second world).  That was the only disappointing element I found (maybe there will be more shift between later worlds?).  Overall, it is a wonderful game and a worthy purchase for anyone who likes puzzle/platforming games.

												Well, it's a work of art, and it singlehandedly reinvented the platforming genre. So, there's that. For those of you who read David Hellman's webcomic (A Lesson Is Learned But The Damage Is Irreversible), it will quite likely be an extraordinarily memorable experience.I actually gave up on one frustrating puzzle only to come back over a year later and see the solution immediately. So yes, the puzzles can be quite challenging, but as there's really only one mechanic to play with, you'll get there eventually with enough patience. The payoff for finishing the game is superb (and even better if you don't cheat). Every gamer should play this. Every person should play this. They should teach this game in high school.

												Definetly the HARDEST game i've ever play !!"Come On. This will not be as hard as you said."Maybe yes. Braid introduces itself with simple puzzles that even 5 yo girl can finish those. But, in a mid-game you will experience new conditions that surely cause you to fail at first and want to give up already. These damn 'barriers' sometimes so annoying and you will struggle with them until the end of game.There are many walkthrough videos which uploaded by those smart guys on community hub and you can just follow those instruction to get all the puzzle pieces quite easily. But, will you still getting scared by a horror movie when you're already know when those ghosts will appear? Same goes with BRAID, the real experience come if you try to solve the puzzles by yourself.Other than that, Braid gives some heavenly soothing atmosphere through good music and nice graphic. These things are what i think the best part of this game. There also will be many references of many old popular games you have played before.In my conclusion, this game is not for everyone (as others told it too) but for you who likes puzzles and willing to strrugle with them will find yourself immersed in the game and somehow addicted to it. Giving it 8/10 (because it's hard).

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Is there anything left to say about Braid that has not already been said a thousand times through the years? It was one of those games that defined the emerging indie scene that proved you don’t need a multinational entertainment company or a suicidal Japanese developing team to produce a great game. All it took was the sacrificial offering of one man and his career. Years later Braid is still one of the defining indie games that anyone interested in modern gaming just has to play. If you had the luck of living under a rock these last years it’s still one of the most climatic endings a 10 hour time investment  can offer. It’s simply put a game for the history books.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2012
												Braid is an intriguing game where you use the power to rewind time to solve a variety of platform puzzles. As you progress through the game, you encounter new and different effects that give each level a unique challenge. Although there is some written plot, the game is driven mostly by player action.The biggest turnoff I've found for this game is that it was very poorly ported from console. You *can* use a keyboard, but its very uncomfortable and goes against keyboard control standards. And you can't change them. On top of that, you can't change any video settings, not even to go from fullscreen to windowed mode or the resolution. For my multi-monitor setup, that is annoying and distracting.Overall, I say this game is very much worth playing. However, I strongly advise playing it in its native console form.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
"Simple, yet overwhelmingly astonishing. This is Braid. "Braid was told to me by someone in a forum, being an overlooked game and all. So after a year, I finally tried it out when it went sale. And...There's a lot to compliment about Braid, and I'll start with the art style. It is magnificent. Wonderful hand painted-like backgrounds to 2D variations sprites of these hand painted-like objects in the game. Everything good about aesthetics, this game has.Next is the plot. It is a story about a rather looking middle-aged man named Tim, that traverses different worlds from his house to find and rescue a "Princess". There are only a few noticeable characters, and, including Tim, are all very odd. The game offers a rather...no...very surreal plot, in a way that not everyone would understand, and probably it's intended best that way, for the people themselves to leave it to their imagination. I would like to talk about the ending, but I'll just spoil you guys. Which I would have to say, one of the most surreal endings I've seen yet.Finally the game's mechanics. It is a puzzle-platformer. 'Nuff said, but is it a good one? Yes, it's VERY GOOD at what it does. The system is so unique, that it contrasts your average platformers, and it provides a unique mechanic in every world. With that, it takes away the "redundancy" we see in most platformers. The system's mechanics are divided into two: The Basic Mechanics; and The World's Mechanics. The Basic Mechanics is supposedly Tim's otherworldly powers, which is controlling Time, either reversing it, forwarding it, or stopping it, but Tim goes along with the Time's flow, he does not stop in one point when he controls it, unless he has Time Immunity. The World's Mechanics, is how the World's reacts to everything, including Tim. The variation will differ in every new world. An example would be, that in one world, as Tim moves forward, everything moves forward, but when he moves backwards, everything moves backwards, disregarding him controlling Time to reverse time. As in another world, everything just moves backwards.The game has no deaths. Whenever you die, you'll just be prompt to reverse time, so that you can prevent what killed you in the first place. The puzzles are literally two parts; the platforming puzzle, and the puzzle pieces you actually collect. Does it have hints? No. The introduction to controls are rather a-blurred, that if you don't know how Braid works at first, you'd find that you can control time when you die. It's not a game for casuals...I would think that, but...the game has no deaths, as I've said.The platforming is brutally hard per se, but I'm pretty sure everyone with decent puzzle-platforming skills can manage it. So long they get used to the game's mechanics. Lifespan is more or less 5 hours if you're a decent puzzle-platform gamer. As you would see in my game time, that will include the time I had breaks, like alt-tabs. But that excludes(for now) the "Hidden" stuff, that you people would know later on.Overall, it truly is a magnificent game. Probably as people say, it is an overlooked game amongst others, but I would greatly recommend this to everyone who enjoys puzzles and platforming. Verdict: 10/10

If you can get it on sale, check it out!Braid is good, but I feel like the game is a little bit overhyped. Personally, I'm not a huge fan of platformers to begin with, but this game does bring something new to the table. The levels are interesting, for sure - lots of time-and-space based puzzles, which I thought was a neat take on platforming. It's a little like Prince of Persia and Mario had a lovechild.Braid's worth giving a shot, but I'd wait to pick it up on a sale. The play time feels just about right, but I doubt whether I'd feel the same way if I had paid full price.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												Braid is a courageous endeavor, seeking to redefine not only the puzzle genre but the platforming one as well. And while it does well to both improve and reinvent those genre's it still falls just a little short of the target.Braid time control mechanic is quite ingenious although it has since been topped by other games, the main problem with this incarnation of it being that it encourages nothing not replays. To complete Braid, and in particular to complete the achievements, Braid forces you to play the same 5 second tidbits of game over and over again until you get it just right. And repetition is never an entertaining game mechanic.The visual style and music is quite interesting but nothing out of this world and the storyline, if you can call it that, is pretentious and not that well written.Braid is a good little game, it just isn't quite as good as all the hype built up around it. It's fun enough just don't expect it to produce any revelations about the world of gaming.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2011
												Belated review. Braid is one of the coolest games you will ever play. The mind-warping, time-bending 2D platforming puzzle goodness ranks right up there with the best of 'em. It is just one of those games that can't be missed. The only thing I didn't care for all that much was the somewhat pretentious "story" that meanders behind the scenes throughout the game. It didn't really add or detract from the experience, it just felt like that author was trying too hard to be "deep" or something (just my personal feeling). That aside, I can't find one negative thing to say about Braid. Give it a try. I guarantee you have never, and may never, play any other game like it. It's a really well designed and sometimes challenging game with great puzzles and original gameplay mechanics that will stick with you for a long time.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Braid is a simple puzzle platformer, or at least at the first glance. Gameplay is incredibly smooth and well done along with all the time tricks you get to experience throug the levels. You'll love the relaxing "classical" music and overall soft and chill appeal in whole design.The trick is the first glance of simplicity wears off quite fast and you are going to get stuck. Often. Braid is by far the hardest puzzle game I've ever played. This is truly going to test how patient and clever you are. You are going to be frustrated at times, but at the same time each puzzle is going to give you a great feeling of accomplishment if you are patient enough to solve it on your own. None of the puzzles are dumb or repetitive and each brings a new pattern to uncover and understand.About the story - I must say I enjoyed the sentimental style and slow uncovering of it, but most of the time I was quite confused and had no idea what it was all about. Well, I definitely experienced better storytelling in games, but this game won my gaming soul just by its crisp gameplay.

												One of the most bester puzzle games. The puzzles are very well-designed and the difficulty scales up reasonably so that while it is challenging, it isn't impossible. Figure the puzzles out yourself. It is very satisfying.The story is short but adequate, though the symbolism is kind of lame.The only gripe I have is that it is much too short. You could probably finish the game in a few hours on your first try, though you may get stuck for hours on some later puzzles. Also, one of the "hidden" achievements of getting the stars and the "alternate ending" is likely impossible without viewing a walkthrough because some stars are hidden in the middle of nowhere (i.e., one star takes almost two hours to get).

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
Pros:[/b]Amazing artistic direction; classical soundtrack; variety in puzzle mechanics; fantastic final level.Cons:[/b]Ambiguous story completely separated from the gameplay won't suit everyone; music may get repetitive; hidden secrets are barely hinted.My veridict:[/b]Braid's perhaps pretentious delivery of its plot will not suit those who prefer a more direct approach, but it's a must play for those who enjoy puzzle platforming.Full review:[/b]Repent, then, and turn to God, so that your sins may be wiped out, that times of refreshing may come from the Lord, (Acts 3:19 NIV)Setting religious matters aside, it is safe to say that every human being has at some point in his or her life repented for an action of theirs."What would have come to me had I done the opposite?""If only I could turn back time."These are common sentences from those wishing to repeat past events in hopes of a better outcome. Sadly to them, they are still unable to do so, but not Tim, the protagonist in Braid, Jonathan Blow's puzzle platformer. At a certain point in his life, Tim lost someone very dear to him and thus he enters a quest for finding that someone, whom we only know as "the Princess". In his attempt to correct apparently permanent mistakes, Tim is able to rewind time, never having to suffer the consequences of a wrong decision. With this in mind, can Tim really lose anything in this journey?The protagonist's travels are set in different worlds, divided in different levels, and the goal is quite simple: use Tim's abilities to solve platforming puzzles, collect every puzzle piece (literally) and reach the end of the level. At the beginning of each world, before entering any level, the player is presented with short books, explaining Tim's past and his relationship with the Princess. The plot, completely separated from the gameplay, is delivered in such an ambiguous manner that the player is mostly left with questions, pressing on hoping for an answer, but the princess always seems to be in another castle, as we are often told. Who is the princess?Time manipulation, often accompanied by platforming, is the gameplay's bread and butter, each world introducing and/or replacing new time mechanics, resulting in a great variety of puzzles. Braid isn't a game that gets easier as you grow accustomed to each ability, because you'll soon abandon it and be forced to completely readapt your thought process. The level "Fickle Companion" is a prime example of how becoming used on certain mechanics will stop you on your tracks until you begin to think again. It's a challenging game, but not in a way that will force you to abandon it. As you find a solution you'll notice how deceptibly simple it actually was. The superposition of platforming and time manipulation is so organic that it results in the most dinamically entertaining puzzles, while those who are solely time manipulation usually require more abstract thinking, usually being the most difficult.Most of Braid's $200,000 budget went to the game's artwork, developed by David Hellman. Every level has a lush pallet of colours and painted backgrounds, akin of an oil paiting. A forest in a yellowish tint, a cloudy blue sky, a city at sunset (or is it burning?) are a few examples of Hellman's glourious results. Would the game have delivered the same experience had the developer not invested in this artistic direction? We'll never know, because we lack Tim's abilities.The music throughout the game is mostly delivered by Jami Sieber and Shira Kammen, resulting in a classical touch, which actually influenced the above mentioned artwork and actually help setting the game's mood. The prime examples are Kammen's "Downstream", which is an adaptation of Luar Na Lubre's "O son do ar" (Galician: The sound of air) and Sieber's "Undercurrent". The former is commonly used earlier in the game, when the story is at its gentlest, while the latter, much darker, is reserved for latter moments, namely the final levels. There is, however, little variety of music, which may tire those who are searching for an expansive soundtrack.Despite its flaws in storytelling and an ending, which despite being amazing, leaves lots of questions unanswered, Braid is an important piece in the most recent rise of independent gaming popularity. Its sometimes challenging puzzles will quench the thirst of those looking for a challenge of the minds, but will not appeal to those who prefer more action in their games. Will Tim ever find the princess? It's up to the player to find out.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												Everybody makes mistakes. After all to err is human, but what if we revisit our past, fix the problems we create and come out the better for them? This is the crux of Braid, a game that at it's core, is about someone who has done something very bad and is now doing everything in their power to wind back the clock and make amends. Eloquently penned and highly symbolic it tells a story with a deliberate purpose, the details of which have been picked and scrutinized over. It's meant to be open ended, to inspire discussion, and ultimately to make you sit and ponder the outcome, which speaking purely from my own perspective caught me entirely off guard and was cause enough for me to pause and step away from it to contemplate what it all meant.Built around the narrative (or perhaps the other way around) are the puzzles which again deal with the manipulation of time. At first it's simply a way out of the inevitable mishaps you get into, but as you progress they evolve into much more elaborate and inventive conundrums, continually changing up the rules while keeping the framework intact. Again and again I was astounded by the simple elegant way everything fit together, much like the jigsaw pieces you collect, each part feeling necessary and fleshed out. This goes a long way in keeping the puzzles challenging and absorbing, and although it is a short experience developer Jonathan Blow makes smart use of his time and doesn't waste yours with filler or sections that fall flat from poor execution.The rich pastel backdrops that blend effortlessly with the stunningly animated sprites, create a scene that looks like a watercolor painting in motion. It's absolutely beautiful and perfectly matches the tone of the narrative, further complemented by the soundtrack which flows alongside it in time, seemingly telling its own story in the process. It's an artistic masterpiece that captivated and enchanted me the moment I laid eyes upon it, and the organic pacing kept me wholly engrossed throughout.If you only play one puzzle-platformer in your time, Braid would be very close to the top of my list. It personifies the genre better than almost anything that came before it or after, and did so before the genre was anywhere near as prolific as it is today. If for some reason the story doesn't grab you the brilliant puzzle designs will, and those that look deeper be duly rewarded with what has been placed beneath the surface. I savored my time with it and am now, like our protagonist, wishing I could go back and relive it over again.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Braid was floating around Steam for quite some time before I gave it a second look. I had heard many great things about Braid and knew there were some great reviews for it. Still, I wasn't as attracted to the game as I had hoped to be. Eventually it went on sale, and I thought, "Why not?" That weekend, I gave Braid a try; it blew me away.Presentation: 9/10The game starts off with a simple notion and subtly nudges you along, presenting you with simple concepts and well-written segments at the beginning of each world. The exquisite literature within these "books" help lay the foundation and reason for your journey, and as you progress through the game, you'll continuously find yourself connecting to our hero and his ambitions and goals.Graphics: 9/10Simple, yet elegant, the artstyle brings about a strong aura of innocence to accompany the story and its protagonist. The amount of detail put into the game's artistic world is stunning, and you'll often find yourself pausing for several seconds to admire its beauty. The artwork resembles that of some paintings and really gives you the feel of a game crafted with love.Sound: 9/10The music is calm and wants to lull you into its world. Soothing and conveyance of innocence in Braid, the soundtrack meshes well with the artistic representation of the game.Gameplay: 8.5/10Thought provoking at times, the puzzles were never made to be impossible and required a little perserverence and patience to complete. The basic concepts shown in the beginning of each world quickly expands and tests your intelligence with different situations that require some "out-of-the-box" thinking. As if that weren't enough, there's even an option to complete a speed-run of the game.Overall: 9/10I wholeheartedly agree that this gem deserves more attention. A short and powerful game that throws simple concepts with increasingly challenging puzzles, coupled with an innocent story yearning for companionship and great music: a game that no one should pass if given the opportunity.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												One of my all time favourite games.Braid tells a nice sad story. Its a perfect blend of story telling and puzzle platform action.The game itself reminds me of Super Mario with the monsters a bit like goomba troopers but with afro hair cuts. The puzzles will have you scratching your head while you figure out the different ways to complete them. Its broken up nicely into several different worlds and each world has its feature. See this is the interesting thing about Braid. Its the ability to go back in time. You can rewind and take yourself back in time and do it again if you screwed up. They work it nicely into the puzzles also with you having to rewind time as certain aspects in a level are sometimes not affected by the rewind. Sometimes this is a key to open a door or its a cannon or even a monster.There is a lot of replayability to Braid. Once you complete the game normally you then have the challenges. Once you've done the challenge you have the ultimate time challenge... complete the whole game in one sitting in a time limit and the time limit leaves very little room for error. Which in itself can be a bit frustrating when you reach the last level and screw something up on the last part of the game.I couldn't recommend this game more. buy it.... NOW!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Puzzle platformer reborn. What to say about this game that hasn't been already said ? Well when I first got it, I was like yeah yeah yet another super mario clone. But then I started to submerge into it while me and my frieds were playing it and I started to realise how deep this game is. It loves to play hide and seek, loves dualities and metaphores. Nothing is as it seems at first glance...*Minor spoiler ahead*The 'home page' isnt a home page but a world of its own, the relationship with a princess isn't real, but it's rather a reflection of the protagonists conciousness, the world, the princess aren't real either they are metaphors for lost innocence that can never be retrieved no matter how hard we push... even the music composer hides her identity under a musculine name... It's hard to say more withou spoiling it for you, so if you like check the hidden meaning on the internet. But once you realise it you will never look at the game the same way. It's very dark even thoug it's trying to hide it behind its chlildish lookShould I recommend it ?Definitelly yes! Its a great game, very inventive in many ways, even without caring about the background story. It plays nice, has an interesting game mechanics never seen elsewhere and a very, very dark atmosphere once you understand it... For me this represents everything that I expect from a game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Braid is a 2-D puzzle platform game where time control is the key game mechanic. There are a few places where quick reflexes are required, but for the most part solving the puzzles just requires figuring out the right sequence of actions. Most of the puzzles are intuitive yet difficult and require a lot of thought to solve. A few puzzles were so difficult that I had to consult a video walkthrough. The goal of the game is to collect puzzle pieces, and then assemble the puzzle on a canvas. The puzzles are artsy-fartsty paintings which are pretty decent, and it is trivial yet fun to put the puzzle together. There are also books in the game that contain pieces of a story. Just like the paintings, the developer is trying to get artsy-fartsy with this story as well. For me the story was too disjointed and "out there" for me, but this does not really detract from the game. The art and music for the game are very good. I played this game with a game controller on my PC, it is probably a bit harder to play in on a keyboard. Overall it is an excellent game that I can strongly recommend. If you like this game, you might like these 2-d puzzle games: Limbo, Vessel, The Swapper. You might also try 3-d puzzle games Portal, Portal 2, and Antichamber.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												You've probably heard it all before, but here goes:One of the most immersive experiences one can have. The fact that the story isn't just laid out for you to read trough and must actually put tought into it, coupled with the fact that the gameplay elements themselves are an important part of it can cause a much higher sense of accomplishment and even trigger some fairly strong feelings.The graphics and estethics are amazing. The assets were litterally painted and digitized, and it shows - almost everything looks gorgeous. There's really little to say about it, and screenshots don't do it justice, just see it for yourself.The music fits right in. Very atmospheric, yet still at times very melodic. A better soundtrack could not be wished for.The puzzles are varied and interesting, often times quite difficult to figure out, even. And that's just the basic ones - there are hidden puzzles within puzzles that unlock something special, and those are _really_ mindbending sometimes. Each "world" comes with it's own set of rules and capabilities, and most of them are quite amazing.I, personally, have only two complaints about it: 1) the bunny-cat-flower things are make way too high-pitched noises, and 2) at some points there are doors (completely indistinguishable from regular ones) that break your key and don't open. That's just a cheap shot.Other than that, I can't fault almost anything about it.Go get it, and enjoy it - almost guaranteed you will.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Braid was floating around Steam for quite some time before I gave it a second look. I had heard many great things about Braid and knew there were some great reviews for it. Still, I wasn't as attracted to the game as I had hoped to be. Eventually it went on sale, and I thought, "Why not?" That weekend, I gave Braid a try; it blew me away.Presentation: 9/10The game starts off with a simple notion and subtly nudges you along, presenting you with simple concepts and well-written segments at the beginning of each world. The exquisite literature within these "books" help lay the foundation and reason for your journey, and as you progress through the game, you'll continuously find yourself connecting to our hero and his ambitions and goals.Graphics: 9/10Simple, yet elegant, the artstyle brings about a strong aura of innocence to accompany the story and its protagonist. The amount of detail put into the game's artistic world is stunning, and you'll often find yourself pausing for several seconds to admire its beauty. The artwork resembles that of some paintings and really gives you the feel of a game crafted with love.Sound: 9/10The music is calm and wants to lull you into its world. Soothing and conveyance of innocence in Braid, the soundtrack meshes well with the artistic representation of the game.Gameplay: 8.5/10Thought provoking at times, the puzzles were never made to be impossible and required a little perserverence and patience to complete. The basic concepts shown in the beginning of each world quickly expands and tests your intelligence with different situations that require some "out-of-the-box" thinking. As if that weren't enough, there's even an option to complete a speed-run of the game.Overall: 9/10I wholeheartedly agree that this gem deserves more attention. A short and powerful game that throws simple concepts with increasingly challenging puzzles, coupled with an innocent story yearning for companionship and great music: a game that no one should pass if given the opportunity.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												I barely wish for a game to have thumb that is neither up or down but just kinda "meh". Right there in the middle. On the other side I do not like it to have a "meh" opinion. DAMN YOU BRAID! :DNow, I know this game has been praised all up and down for being amazing, and it is. Except for the times when it is not. To me, the most interesting parts about Braid are the art style and the core gameplay mechanic. While I can't do anything but praise the style of the game as well I will do so. Be praised Art Style! Your rock!The core mechanic, however, is a double edged sword. It basically is all about turning back and replaying time. You can do so manually at all times or sometimes you'll have a special time mechanic on your hands:In example, when your movement is queued to the entire game world. Walking forward will move you and the time, standing still will freeze it and walking backwards will rewind it. There are quite a few different time mechanics within Braid, but since I'm not all that evil I won't do spoilers here.Oh yeah you can walk and jump here. That's like the platforming part. It's solid but nothing special without the time travel thingy.While this makes for an amazingly fresh gameplay experience, some of the puzzles tied to it are ridiculous. You'll spend hours upon hours to solve a single game screen just to get frustrated as hell, turning to a youtube guide if your computer can still play videos after you've tossed it through your entire apartement, out the window and ran it over with a truck. Twice. Some of the puzzles later on even require the usage of tricks never hinted at, let alone explained wich just seems cheep.There may be the 1% of players who will dedicate their live to solving those puzzles without a guide but there's a 1% of people who try to invent time travel itself in the real world as well without much success. So yeah. Another interesting thing are the collectables. You can run through almost the entire game, skipping all puzzles. Now it won't do you and good and you'll be done with the Braid within 15 minutes. So don't do it. Embrace the rage! By collecting certain things you'll uncover other certain things wich will uncover 6 very certain things and the games ending. Wich in itself is a thing. So ya. Getting those collectables is the goal of the game.There are a few more things I wanna praise here to look in the mirror tomorrow morning, hating myself for being mainstream or something.Yet another great apsect this game does have for it is the music. it's great. I do have the feeling that it is intendet to calm you while the hate about not solving puzzles inside you does grow to an infinite amount of pure rage. Just like the visual part of the game it feels "real". As in, all hand made. A warm piano accompanied by a soothing Cello charm your ears while you are afraid of blowing up the house on the other side of the street if your speakers fail to work all of a sudden. Or if you use the time mechanic (wich you have to) for it will rewind the soundtrack as well wich sounds god awful. So basically, the music makes you afraid of solving the game... Soundtrack, you've nailed it! Except for the fact that you make me staring at the screen not doing much at all cause I am afraid of rewinding you.The story is surprisingly deep for a puzzle platformer. Not deep in the sense of an epic story that will unfold before you but deep as in you'll find yourself thinking about it... in fact, Braid is kinda vague on the story thing with a bunch of diaries as your only lore. But those diaries are, in fact, very well written and thought worthy... You'll (or can... there are those people) squeeze your thoughts in a philosophical attempt, triggered by those diaries in the game... with about 30% of your brain cells while the other 70% will be occupied crafting a pipe bomb you'll stick into your computer, watching it blow up in satisfaction about the running gamescreen fading to black while you'll get caught into the explosion. Story, you are awesome! Kind of.... Kant would like it I suppose.... or Tolstoi. Maybe...(Dat ending though.... 12/10)There are more likable aspects about this game (like dropping huge objects on people and jumping on heads) wich do result in the same awesome but not awesome part of the game. In the end, it is indeed a great game wich you should buy but it also sucks♥♥♥♥♥for it will ruin your day whenever you start it. Wich probably means you shouldn't buy it.So buy it! Or not! I dunno. You'll have to answer yourself a simple question: Is the massive frustration worth the whole lot of joy you'll get from this game? I do not regret buying it at all but damn! This new computer was expensive!Yet again... dat ending though! 13/10!(if there are any typos I DON'T CARE CAUSE I'M RAGING!)Oh did I meantion the ♥♥♥♥ing impossible to beat speed mode? I didn't? Shame on me!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												A lot of hipsters will tell you this is undeniably one of the most deeply thought out games ever made. Most hardcore gamers will tell you it's a bunch of crap disguising itself to be deeper than it is. There's a line out there somewhere. As someone who's into walking simulator's and artsy ♥♥♥♥ing games, I'm probably not gonna win many fans with this review. The truth is, this is a pretty good puzzle platformer, gameplay wise. And to be honest, not a lot of artsy games are very good at being games. The game that this was inspired by from the 70's, Trinity, was a deeply moving text adventure about time and the bomb, and the gameplay on that do not translate well, so it is actually better than it's inspiration in terms of, you know, being a game The puzzles range from slightly challenging to slightly difficult, and you'll feel pretty clever solving them. That said, fickle companion is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and don't kick yourself for using a guide on a particular puzzle, some are very challenging. I am not great at puzzles and will admit I looked up two or three, just to see if I was on the right track.  As for the atomic bomb allegory, eh that's for you to decide. It could be a tale representing regret, but really, if you feel like there's some deeper meaning you're not getting, don't freak out, very few people actually think they have a grasp on the theme, and none of them can agree. If nothing else just know there's regret and no going back, possibly an atomic bomb, but definitely fun puzzles and beautiful music.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Bullet points:Very prettyHas pleasant musicCreative puzzles/mechanicsChallenging without being frustrating (mostly)Full ending is ridiculously hard to getObnoxiously beats you over the head with metaphorsBraid is a very clever little puzzle game with gentle, pleasant music.  It's not super difficult but it's not exactly easy, either - it falls into a nice "kind of challenging but not frustrating" place - that is, unless you want to unlock the true ending.  Moving through the levels and collecting the puzzle pieces is a fun affair, but the 8 special puzzles for unlocking the alternate ending range from fun to "the developer is giving me a giant middle finger and I don't know what I did to deserve this."  I have been told that the sadistic difficulty/tedium of some of the special puzzles is a metaphor.Your character, a cute little guy in a suit coat named Tim, starts off with the ability to stop, rewind, or fast-forward time, which he retains throughout the game.  At first this is mostly used to rewind mistakes, but as you progress you'll find several other uses for it.  As you enter each new area you will be given small pieces of writing about moments of Tim's life.  The little vignettes are nicely written and interesting to read.  They are mostly unrelated to the actual story, but they tell us about Tim's character and set an appropriate tone for each setting with hints at that level's special ability.  Each area also has a simple jigsaw puzzle to collect and assemble.  The images in the puzzles are unrelated to the story.  I have been told that the images in the puzzles are metaphors.The overall story is...  About 95% of the time it seems to be a spoof of the original Mario games taken to a strange extreme: Tim is an eccentric dude with an obsessive personality, and he is totally fixated on finding a princess.  In the last area or two it then beats you over the head while screaming "It was a metaphor!!"  Frankly it's a bit obnoxious.  If you have the patience to collect all of the extra objects for the true ending, the game will explain the metaphor in detail (but it's easy to figure out even with the ending that doesn't explicitly come out and say it).To summarize:  This is a fun puzzle-platformer with an eye-rollingly pretentious story.  Metaphors.  Metaphors.  Metaphors.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												I really wanted to like this game because of other people praising it. I thought this game would be fun with the time manipulation concepts but I am finding all of it confusing and tedious, making it really hard to enjoy the game. I feel like the mechanics are just throwing themselves all at once at me and the developer is just expecting the player to know what to do instinctively. When I do get something working, often I feel it was just through dumb luck more so than analyzing the situation and executing to see if my strategy would work. This could have been avoided if the concepts were introduced better and how to take advantage of each one.I also feel that the game is cheating me, like I obtain a key and then I lose it if I backtrack (not rewind). I do realize that a green "aura" object or enemy is immune to time manipution, but other things, such as moving right makes enemies "play forward" while moving left makes enemies "play backwards", isn't clearly marked. I think that particular key is that kind of object but I just gave up after not understanding why I was losing the key.For some reason, the game likes to shift between 30 and 60FPS. This isn't frame skipping. This is kind of annoying because the game started out slow and then suddenly became faster and then become slow again. I don't understand why.I do applaud the developers for trying to do something ambitious but I don't think it was designed well in execution. It might be an indie game and not a AAA game, but that doesn't automatically mean good. The art style and music playback of rewinding, fast-forwarding, and slow-motion distortion are interesting to see and hear come from a game, but that's all I can really say is good about it. The rest is just meh to me. I don't think this game was meant for me. I'm glad I gave it a try though. At least I know it's not for me.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												It feels insufficient to give only a thumbs up. This game - if given space and time for thought, is one of the more rewarding platformers to emerge from the new Indie era. Dozens of games have been trying to achieve this meshing of subtle emotional storytelling, unique design, beautiful art direction, and fantastic score. Almost none have even come close. If you are frustrated by difficulty, this may not be for you, but beyond that narrow caveat - this is really a game for everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												This is a fun side-scroller game with an artistic touch.  The environments look like paintings and the character you play looks like a hero you'd see from the old school Mario games.  Actually the gameplay is very much like the old Mario Bros. games.  But, instead of just trying to make it to the end of the level, each level has puzzle pieces you have to collect.  After you've found them all they make a painting.  But it's not as simple as just grabbing the puzzle pieces and exiting the level.  These worlds become more like a puzzle.  The good thing is, you can't really die or screw up too bad.  That's because you can literally rewind your gameplay!  If an enemy hits you just rewind and try again.  The challenges get harder because some worlds react to your movement and some items have magic and can't be changed with the rewind feature.  This game has great artwork, music and a nostalgic feel.  If you like side-scroller puzzle games you'll love this.

content:
Posted: February 25
												It's strange because in theory this is exactly my type of game, but I just wasn't feeling it. I found it far too difficult, to the point where it was so difficult it just wasn't fun at all. Most of the puzzle solutions felt like exploits rather than solutions. Which I think I'd be OK with if the game wasn't real-time with penalty for failure. All of the different time-based gameplay mechanics were interesting and playing around with their implementations was pretty cool, and the puzzles were extremely well-designed - this game is a classic example of introducing some reasonably simple mechanic and then wringing every last gameplay idea out of it just like Nintendo is pretty good at. Only problem is that it just wasn't actually fun.I thought the graphics were... bad (I've never seen something that looked like it was drawn in MS Paint AND looked horribly blurry before), and the music was annoying (not the fault of the music per se but just the fact that it's bound to be annoying when you're constantly rewinding it, pausing it, speeding it up, slowing it down...). The "story" was unintelligible garbage like Hotline Miami - there's metaphorical and then there's just noise.I suppose if you come at this game with the idea that the only thing you want is a sequence of increasingly difficult real-time puzzles, and you're happy that the game will give you absolutely nothing except those puzzles, and you don't already have a headache, you could enjoy it just fine. But silly me, I tried to pay attention to the story, I expected low-stress areas between high-stress areas, I expected the game to explain its mechanics to me (don't need to explain everything, but the arbitrary/esoteric corner cases of the less obvious abilities, that are necessary for progression? yes), and I already had a headache when I started.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												It's very hard to tell someone how amazing this game is without spoiling parts of it. The puzzles are splendidly designed, testing your wit, memory and reflexes.This is by no means an easy game. There are times where you will want to give up or look up walkthroughs. Don't. The minute you figure out and say "Oh yeah!" is the best feeling ever, and this game gives it to you in bundles. For €8.99 this is a steal. This is worth so much more. No puzzle game (with the exception of Fez) has given me the same sense of wonder and awe of the beautiful world on my screen. "Beautiful, entertaining, and inspiring" is the best way to sum up this game. Do yourself a favour and buy it. Now. Play it til your fingers bleed from trying to solve puzzles, because it's worth it in the end.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Years late, I finally experience Braid.The art direction, sound direction, music, and gameplay concept are all completley superb. There is nothing quite like Braid, and it certainly inspired many other games to try and tackle the really unique ways it convoluted Time.However, I found Braid to be incredibly confusing and difficult. It made me feel like a simpleton most of the time, with solutions to puzzles feeling more like abusing the mechanics than using the mechanics in a natural fasion. Furthermore, the diffiuclty curve never felt like a curve, but more a square-wave function.After consulting a Steam guide many times, I was finally able to finish the game. Having robbed myself of the satisfaction of actually figuring out the game, it felt a bit flat. Despite my issues with it, the game stands out as a great technical and aesthetic achievement.Well worth it, especially if you've a mind for puzzles like this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Such a beautiful game and also so clever. I haven't finished yet, but one of the many great things about Braid is that it gives you some freedom to explore and see the world(s) before knuckling down and solving puzzles.And the puzzles are often a complete delight. There's a huge amount of satisfaction to be had from suddenly realising how to reach that previously unobtainable key or picture piece. And hey, if your platforming skills aren't quite up to getting there on the first try, you can always rewind time to do it again...The game teaches you about the gameplay mechanics in marvellously inventive ways that make you want to discover the next trick.  And then, when you pull yourself back from what you're doing for a moment, you'll be reminded again that the whole thing looks and sounds gorgeous.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2011
												With all the artistic praise Braid has received, I came in expecting nothing less than literary perfection. To my disappointment, the dialogue in this game is some of the cheesiest I've ever read from anywhere. I may not be able to do better, but if you're going to make this a story oriented platformer, at least try to make sound less like a fifth grader's attempt at writing a mystery novel.With that said, Braid is a great game. It's music suits the atmosphere very well as do the visuals. But those details pale in comparison to gameplay. At heart, Braid is a puzzle game, despite its platforming setup. A good majority of the puzzles require players to use time manipulation, with solutions that are both frustrating and clever.No doubt there will be times you'll be stuck. My best advice is to never use a walkthrough because solving each puzzle will make you feel immensely rewarded. Instead, if you must, look for hints online (I admittedly did so a few times!), not answers.Grade: B+

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												Braid is…A stunning painterly adventure through a platformed word and the history of a relationship.From the starting sequence, I was in love, it started so simply control was instinctual move and jump, got it! I was engaged, the emotion you can feel in it narrative, is real. This game served as an emotional outlet for its creator and that element of Braid makes it feel very sacred. That is where my love affair with Braid begins and ends.Braid loses me when the time control function comes into play. I have gotten no introduction to this mechanic. it is just all the sudden mandatory to move forward. This now feels like the first REAL OKG review. This mechanic and the way it controls both on screen and on the controller have ended my experience with this game.Here is what this actually looks like, I am sorry I don't have a stream, that is coming soon. Play along with me though.Camera fades from black and iris open to a wide angle shot. Liz is sitting facing her monitor, controller in hands, grin on face and feet at the ready under her chair.The soft hum of in-game music can be heard in contrast to the clicking of nails against a plastic controller. Full attention is focused on the monitor that glows before her. As you watch Tim, the on-screen avatar bounce around platforms and off enemy heads you can see Liz hold her breath and her mouth tense just a little each time she presses the jump button to send Tim soaring.She is still progressing but the grin has faded and her shoulders have rolled forward . Then she gets here, this screen shows the end of this game for our Okayest Gamer, Liz Cooper.So what does OKG say?So after experiencing my masochistic attempts at progress in this game, what do you think I am going to say here? If you are an OKG like me, there is a chance this mechanic might catch you up too, but maybe not. I would try a friend's copy before buying to see if you are all clear, or maybe just add to Steam Wishlist and get when on deep discount during a sale.If you do not have OKG tendencies, then you are a lucky devil and in for a wonderful experience. I have watched  youtube playthroughs of more successful players, and it is a fantastic game with such emotionally strong narrative. Settle in for a great game and some life lessons on the side.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game was exactly what I hoped it would be. A well designed puzzle-platformer with time mechanics. The game isn't very long, but it is definitely a case of quality over quantity. There are a few levels that get repeated, but I think it is done in a very interesting way; it doesn't feel like filler.There is a deeper meaning to this game if you choose to look for it. But it's main strength is the quality of the puzzles. Some of them are ingenious, and most of them have very simple yet abstract solutions. One of the most satisfying puzzle games I have played in a long while.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												Amazing game play mechanics, seriously challenging puzzles and an incredibly deep story with beautiful art. Manipulating time has never been so fun! You traverse through each of the five worlds, collecting puzzle pieces that are very difficult to get. Once I started playing, I couldn't stop. After completing the game, try the speed challenges to really test your skills. It took me an agonizing (but oh so enjoyable) 6 hours to play through the entire game without any breaks and help. Now I'm ready to beat the entire game+collecting all puzzle pieces in under 45min for the speed challenge achievement. Old school gamers will enjoy the Mario references too :)Overall, a great game with great storytelling! You must add this to your game collection!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												An inventive & unique action puzzle game that revolves around the manipulation of time to solve various puzzles, with an interesting & thought provoking storyline that has hidden dark layers & undertones beneath the colorful semi-cartoony graphics. Progressing through the game & solving the variety of diverse puzzles is certainly brain-teasing, & while some may leave you totally stumped at times, Braid is the type of game where as you are running around experimenting the answer will hit you all of a sudden & keeps you coming back for more. You can't die in Braid, but don't let that fool you into thinking this game is somehow lacking in difficulty. It's definitely quite challenging & just when you think you have solved it all there are secrets hidden throughout the game. While the game is not that long the experience will certainly leave its mark upon you. Thanks to Braid I now pay a lot more attention to indie games because there are some real gems out there. Also can't wait for "The Witness", the follow-up to this from lead developer Jonathan Blow.

												Amazing and inspiring little game! Maybe not the longest one out there. The story is a little confusing just like the whole game that seems so mysterious. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												At first glance it may look like a hipster version of Mario { something it's not shy about hinting at itself } but at it's core Braid is more of a puzzle game with a platformer interface. It is at times very challenging and fighting the urge to do a search on youtube for the way to clear an area could be tough for many people. Visually it has a timless art style which keeps it seperate from the graphic spec' fights of contempory titles and as a 2D game it is not overly taxing on the machine it is played on. The Story, though hidden in a way, is actually quite deep & somber but i'll not spoil it. The length of the game is on the short side but for most people the puzzels will slow them down enough to get a good few gaming sessions out of it.Gameplay wise, it is inventive and surprisingly intuitive. There is little need for any tutorial beyond trying out the variations on the mechanics each world brings. The real downside is probably the replayabillity once you have collected all of the puzzle-pieces. Speed players may go back to try and beat their time but beyond that not much would bring the player back post completion. While most games out there lately seem to be either clones of other games or made to be easy to beat, this is refreshingly challenging. It looks good and it plays well. If you like platformers and puzzels, get it.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												A unique puzzle game that is one of it's kind. The storyline has very profound meaning behind it.The mechanics and the world kinda remind you of Super Mario Bros, except you manipulate the flow of time instead of shooting fireballs. You literally cannot die as you can always rewind your action. You timing doesn't really matter in this game... Well it does to some extent, but if you made a mistake just rewind it back!Unfortunately this game is kinda short. About 3 hours to complete the story. But It takes more time and dedication to complete all the speed run (which can be quite frustating).Overall, if you are a fan of puzzle game, then you cannot pass on Braid.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												Awesome. It's a quick play, taking about 4 hours to beat if you're not getting secret stars or doing speed runs. The gimmick here is that in each world, time flows differently: sometimes it's normal, sometimes it moves as you move, sometimes you have a time-slowing ring, etc. It's pretty hard, despite the fact that you can reverse time to correct your mistakes. Good luck, and remember: run away if you see any flowers. Where there are flowers, there are killer bunnies (I'm not kidding).

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Braid is an instant indie classic developed by Jonathan Blow. This is truly a wonderful platform game with a nice plot and a twist with the endingIt is an extremely playable platform game and the levels are designed nicely. You will learn new abilities and possibilities with other levels, the story is wonderful and well written. The appearance from the game's background to its graphics are wonderful and seems fairytale like and the music is gentle and it is nice to have it in the background I remeber when watching Indie Game: The Movie (which I highly reecommend watching if you love indie games) and the creator said he was depressed after the release of Braid. Mostly because some early kids' reviews were about the genious physics usage in the game with moving time. I hope he now knows everybody appreciate it for so much more!Braid is and will always be an instant indie classic, and anyone who is anyone should buy this game and give it a try at least. This is one of the few games that I will remember for a while! RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I wanted to like Braid. It's a game that begs to be liked: beautiful, painting-like art, soothing soundtrack, and ingeniously crafted puzzles. It has a complex, well-written storyline that requires a series of intelligent inferences to follow, as well as a whole horde of subtext and interpretation articles written by people far more intelligent than me. It's an intimidating game, too: a game that birthed an entire genre and has become a sort of initiation into indie gaming for many players out there. It's one of those games that, when you're having a conversation about small developer teams and the rise in indie gaming, you just can't ignore.A lot of people make the mistake of equating an industry changing game with a good game, and while Braid is, in truth, a work of art, I struggle to qualify it at as a truly enjoyable experience as a game. The mechanics of Braid revolve around the idea of time-manipulation as a core gameplay element. When your character moves forward, time moves forward. If your character moves backwards, time moves backward. But what starts as a relatively simple and unique method of creative puzzle solving turns into something grotesquely twisted and almost indecipherably complicated. Hard puzzles in a game should never be a bad thing, but puzzles that are so far out of the realm of my thinking that they become nigh unsolvable aren't fun, they're incredibly off-putting.On top of the intensely challenging puzzle-solving aspect of Braid, the game also identifies as a platformer that often tests the reflexes and timing of the player holding the controller. As the game progresses the player must become more and more precise with their control of the main character. Unfortunately, this, in combination with the difficult puzzles, made for a game that I could only play half of—any of the puzzles that weren't too farfetched for me to understand were instead doubly frustrating because they required a precision and sense of timing that my fumbling hands just couldn't seem to fathom.Altogether, Braid's the kind of game whose phenomenal story is somewhat ruined by its gameplay for me. It's the sort of game that I would rather watch someone play through on YouTube and then read about it on the wiki afterwards than sit down with the controller myself. It's a summary game—the kind of thing that when you step back and look at it as a whole, it's a wonderfully enlightening experience, but that experience is drowned out by an incredibly steep learning curve and absurdly convoluted puzzle solutions. Playing Braid is an uphill climb and while the view at the top of that mountain is pretty great, it's not quite worth the struggle to get to it in the first place.
