content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												I watched Indie Game: The Movie and bought this game on sale. After about 4 hours, I did everything except for the speedruns, which I decided weren’t worth my time.The story just seems all over the place, I know it's supposed to be out of order, but what order is it supposed to be in exactly? Reading through the texts, almost nothing seemed to be part of some cohesive story line and nothing was even enjoyable to read. What a terrible epilogue. Far before the end of the game, I had lost all interest in the story, which comes off as pretentious.Puzzle difficulty increases almost exponentially, which would be fine if there was more instruction on your new powers than just "The Pit" levels at the beginning of each world, especially with the ring.The art is also very off-putting to me. The main character, Tim, has this unsettling stare up into the sky, like he’s looking at nothing and his expressions consist of a creepy toothless smile and what looks like a frown maybe? One of the puzzles has the gall to make use of the jigsaw puzzle pieces scattered throughout the game, as if the bland looking platforms are distinct somehow.Most of the music was good, at least the first time I heard it. In world 4, since your movements change time, each level is really only about 8-20 seconds of real music and you get to hear it all distorted and weird for like 30 minutes as you struggle through the puzzles.This game was enjoyable for about 45 minutes and I don’t recommend buying it at full price under any circumstance.Edit: I have since read the Wikipedia article about this game and it just about validates every single problem I had with this game. Blow basically says outright that the story is whatever you thought it was (in my case it was trash). Blow was so pretentious about his game that he didn't think anyone was smart enough to make a soundtrack for it. And again, Tim looks like Chucky.I have also realized that this game is, in fact, not at all as intelligent as it is made out to be. Just because you can't understand something, doesn't make it smart, it doesn't make it a masterpiece. If you want to ponder and reflect on a story, read a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ book, don't play this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												It's indie. The most indie. It's respectable, sure. But was it really worth my time? Eh.Standard puzzle game with platforming elements. Braid is charming in its aesthetic; that's for sure. Classical music plays as you traverse levels filled watercolored backdrops. It has the presentation down, yeah, but its a shame that the rest of the game really doesn't hold up to my standards.A puzzle game lives or dies on its difficulty curve. If puzzles are set up logically, with difficulty that builds over time, then that's standard. However, Braid introduces new mechanics, and then immediately expects you apply these mechanics in extraordinary ways. The game will typically give you one dead simple level, and then dump you into a level where you need to apply something uncommonly or use a trick to get through. No thanks. And while I'm ragging on level design, something feels off about this. Levels are usually longer affairs, with several different separate puzzle compartments. This feeling is exacerbated the longer the game goes on. Really, the idea of having levels as a sort of divider seems more natural and cohesive to me. If puzzles have nothing to do with eachother except that the same mechanics are being used, then why shove them on the same map? I'm not entirely sure what the intent was.I'll be more blunt, Braid is a time waster. Every puzzle in Braid could probably be solved by anyone if they were given enough time to mess around with it. The amount of time you need to waste to get through would vary though. I simply don't have the patience to just waste time until I somehow solve the puzzle. Trying things until you have the solution is not logical. There is no process, the way I see it. There are just some things the game expects you to know. In a game like Dark Souls, that might be passable, but this has no excuses. If a puzzle game doesn't lay itself out in a logical way, there isn't any way to complete it without a walkthrough, or an excess of time to burn. That's a no-no.I guess I'm more lukewarm on this because I've played more interesting puzzle games that feel like less of a waste. The aesthetic is nice, but can we really justify the puzzles when flash games have been around for so much longer? I guess that's my biggest complaint. This entire thing feels like a flash game I had to pay money for. It's older, sure. But like I said, that doesn't hold water when older games did the genre more justice. The Prince of Persia time mechanics are cool and all, but they don't exactly hold the game up on their own. Later mechanics feel even worse when they begin piling on top of eachother. Unless you got the time to burn, you'll probably end up looking up a walkthrough.Speaking of wasting time, I'll mention the books in the clouds. There's several in every room before the start of each world. I felt robbed, because functionally, these books are worthless. Sure, they provide some color to the game, but anyone who's beaten the game will agree that they're really pointless fluff; akin to books found in the Elder Scrolls games. I'd recommend just ignoring them entirely or just being savvy of intentional misdirection by the game developer. Thanks.What else is there to say. Fairly standard puzzling, with a neat little aesthetic. It's ok for what it's worth, sure. I wouldn't exactly call it time well spent. That ending really sealed the deal for me. Instead of making the twist too obvious, Braid decides to lead you on, and then completely switches on you last level. And all this to one of the most played out twists in the book. There are better puzzle games.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2011
												What a mess. If you're going to rip off a game, I guess Mario is a great choice, because he's old as heck and he's Italian so he probably can't sue you in America, but wow, this game fails on every level. The graphics? Apparently they ran out of money after paying for all the concept art, so they just stuck that in and called it a day. The music? Zero autotune, zero electronic effects, zero ANYTHING that would indicate that they did anything other than grab a bunch of instruments and go to town. The gameplay itself? MASSIVE BUGS. I'm talking about TIME GOING BACKWARDS OR STOPPING and all sorts of ridiculous stuff that should never have made it past QA. Honestly this is so buggy that finishing each level is like a puzzle because you have to figure out some clever way past all the game-breaking bugs. This has a really great story, but I would stick with Mario instead.

												Braid was one of the first pretentious indie art games of which we have so many tedious examples nowadays.  It is also a very good game.  Great sountrack and art style, and very fun gameplay that's fairly varied (though the first half is better).  HOWEVER the story is told entirely through mostly meaningless sort of pretentious walls of text at the beginnings of levels, which kind of sucks.  So yeah, except for a fairly brilliant ending sequence I'm not crazy about the story (though the text helps set the atmosphere of the levels, it doesn't go a good job of actually getting anything across), but Braid is worth getting soley for the excellent gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I am still not sure I understand all the mechanics to moving back and forth in time and so on but this is a beautiful but mind bending / making you go insane game rolled into one.   In regards to controls many times I end up button mashing but it isn't a bad control scheme.  It is just a way different type of game with a different control scheme.  Now just because I can't get it all down in terms of controls it doesn't mean you can't.  In terms of the sound track it is pretty good but has annoyed me at times.  In regards to the story I can tell you it seems to be about a relationship between your character and maybe his wife or girlfriend.  It says you are rescuing an abducted princess but I think this is all in your character's mind.  Graphically I think it has some charm to it but if it wasn't for the good game play I think most would regard this as a pretty poor looking game in some ways.  Oh and as for what I said earlier in my review that this is a beauiful game I was not talking about the graphics but about the good it does for your mind.  This game really has you thinking.  I highly recommend this game but you must decide on the price tag that is right for you to buy it.  I won't put a monetary value on this.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Braid is good, but it's not for everybody.I'd first like to say that the game mechanics and oft spoken of time manipulation are unique. The game does well at creating some difficult puzzles which will test a persons mental prowess. I also think that the soundtrack is excellent and that it provided some great background noise which helps to soothe you as you try to figure out the puzzles which are presented.  However, I think that the storyline is very dissatisfying and the reward that you get for finishing the puzzles is likewise a let down. I didn't find the gameplay or the story addicting enough to play it for more than an hour at a time. I thought that the overall look of the game was childish, which can be ok, but in this case rather annoyed me. The ambiguity of the storyline prevented me from feeling any attachment to the protagonist and the damsel in distress doesn't make an appearance until the end of the game. Essentially, the action of the story was never present during gameplay. There were obvious allusions to such gaming classics as Mario and Donkey Kong, but the game is not as nearly as addicting or as fun as those games are. In the end, I expected more from braid. The game was short and although I enjoyed the soundtrack and found the mechanics innovative, that's all there was that impressed me. I recommend it for it's interesting mechanics and soundtrack even though it wasn't as good as I wanted it to be.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												It might say I have next to no time in this game, but that's not true. I've played about 10 hours of it in offline mode; I wound up getting about 2/3 of the way through the game.This game is probably one of the most overhyped ever. It has some unique selling points, though. The art style is good, the story is really cool, and the central power is really awesome. Time control is a really unique power that many games haven't managed to implement well. For a while, braid implements it well--sometimes. Most of the puzzles don't really revolve around you using time reversal as a way to solve puzzles, but just trigger certain things once per level in very specifc circumstances. You're mostly walking around for the whole game.However, every new stage in braid is based around a new "version" of this time control mechanic. This means that the original mechanic doesn't get to grow and be explored in new ways. Let's compare Braid with Portal: in portal, you start off simple, just moving yourself and objects around. Then it gets complicated; you add in turrets, lasers, light bridges, and then movement gels. Every time a mechanic is introduced it _builds_ on the previous ones you've learned and takes the central power in a new direction.In braid, the first power you have is the power to reverse time. This is explored for a bit, then you move on to other worlds. Here's some sample powers: one world has you move around, then "send" a shadow copy of yourself that follows the steps you just took that you have to interact with to solve puzzles. Another has the world run like a music box, where time moves forward as you move right and backward as you walk left. Do these sound related to the first mechanic you learned? Because they're not at all. What's the point of learning the core puzzle mechanic if you're going to drop it in the next world? The game could basically be described as a collection of 6 time-based different puzzle minigames, but not as a puzzle game that follows a good, challenging progression.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Тим — абсолютный эгоцентрик, запертый в себе, неспособный на сопереживание или отождествление себя с другими, на любовь, дружбу, влечение или нежность. Он является абсолютно изолированной единицей, неспособной на взаимоотношения с кем-либо. Его реакции направлены внутрь, они не относятся к мыслительным процессам; его разум — просто инструмент для обслуживания собственных страстей и потребностей; он не способен к полету мысли, обмену идеями; он не соотносит себя ни с чем, кроме собственных физических ощущений. Он — полумертвая, ни на что не реагирующая масса, неспособная давать или получать удовольствие или счастье; соответственно, он, в лучшем случае, абсолютно скучное явление, безобидное пятно, поскольку только те, кто способны воспринимать и принимать других, обладают очарованием. Он застрял на полпути в сумеречной зоне между человеком и обезьяной, но гораздо хуже обезьян, поскольку, в отличие от них, способен испытывать множество негативных чувств — ненависть, ревность, позор, отвращение, вину, стыд, сомнение; более того, он осознает, что он такое, и чего ему недостает.Обуреваемый чувством вины, страхами, стыдом и неуверенностью, обладая, если удается, едва заметными физическими ощущениями, Тим, тем не менее, полностью захвачен желанием ебаться; он переплывет море соплей, перейдет вброд глубокую лужу блевотины величиной в милю, если будет думать, что там его ждет любезная «киска». Он выебет женщину, которую презирает, любую беззубую ведьму, и даже заплатит за это. Почему? Снятие физического напряжения — это не ответ, поскольку для него достаточно мастурбации. Нельзя объяснить это и удовлетворением самолюбия, иначе он не ебал бы детей и трупы.Абсолютно эгоистичный, не способный реагировать, сочувствовать, отождествлять себя с другими, наполненный до краев необъятной, всепроникающей, всепоглощающей сексуальностью, он физически пассивен. Он ненавидит свою пассивность, поэтому считает, что она свойственна женщинам, а мужчины — активны, а затем пытается доказывать, что он существует («доказывать, что он — Мужчина»). Главный его способ доказать это — ебля.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2011
												Braid is probably the best Mario adaptation to the indie scene I have ever seen. This game follows the original format of Mario where you go through different maps jumping through obstacles to eventually reach a castle, only to realize the princess is on a different map. The one thing that makes braid a much more brilliant game is because of its time manipulation mechanics and integrated puzzles within the game. The environment is the puzzle and your skills with time manipulation will ultimately determine whether or not you can beat the puzzle to advance on to the next map. The game feels surreal with bright poppy colors, and the music is soothing and relaxing. The story is very deep and meaningful for a 2d plat former game. An obvious must buy for the indie enthusiast out there.

Posted: September 25, 2015
												This game deserves none of the praise its been given. The narrative is displayed terribly, the level and enemy design is derivative and music is nothing to write home about. To me this game is the videogame equivalent of Duchamp's submission of the urinal as a piece of art back in 1917. But unlike the urinal and Duchamp's this work right here isn't designed to insult and challenge anyone to rethink current trends. It is just a mediocre work pretending to be something great which it isn't in any manner whatsoever, but enough people bought into it to allow that to happen but I guess that is what makes it more similar to modern art than anything else. If you want to read more about how average this game you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2015/09/braid.html.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												I can't really recommend Braid.While it is a great achievement for a single indy developer, the game itself can be extremely frustrating. Not just because the initially nonsensical logic-bending puzzles are difficult (and they are difficult) and not just because the solutions have to be executed with such a high degree of precision that it leads to a lot of frustrating trial and error (and there is a lot of frustrating trial and error), but because the game seems to go out of its way to trip the player up at every possible opportunity, up to and including inatentive blindness kills worthy of the kill-screens of even the most change-hungry arcade cabinets.Yes it has the rewind dynamic, key to it's design, but rather than being an interesting addition it just seems to serve to prevent the game from being just totally impossible to tollerate, and just barely at that, because,  unfortunately, it's inclusion and implementation just doesn't seem enough to justify all of the cheap deaths that seem to be set up at every turn as though intended really just to frustrate.Basically in addition to the core design, Braid also seems to be designed to trip the player up whenever  and wherever possible, essentially putting a pie in the player's face at nearly every step, almost like practical jokes the player should be in on but unfortunately it's one of those things that's not really that funny when it's happening to you.  Braid consistently frustrates; if it had a muted trumpet "waa waa waa waa" everytime it trips the player up with a pie in the face or a slap accross the cheek with with a wet fish no one would recommend anything but uninstalling this game and never touching it again.Braid is a remarkable achievement for a single indy developer, but ultimately, on some level, it really can just feel, at best, like a chore and at worst like some bizarre form of mental abuse, and as a result, does begin to grate, and ultimately to become just kind of repellent. Braid ultimately has effectively conditioned me out of actually wanting to play it, which is a shame because I enjoy puzzle games and I quite like its aesthetic. I'd recommend just enjoying what you can of the demo, up to the point that it starts to irritate; unless you're some kind of sado-masochist (and I guess "to each his own") I don't recommend playing beyond that point.As with many of the other people who've posted their thoughts about Braid, I have to say...I wanted to like Braid...?

												Art serves as a literal backdrop to this creative, original and charming puzzle-platformer that challenges the player to think far beyond button mashing to solve its increasingly complex riddles.  A jigsaw puzzle serves as a reward for each 'world' successfully navigated and fits itself nicely inside a thoughtful story of regret and the desire for a second chance.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												An innovative and fun game that has gaping flaws in it.#1: Difficulty, there were some challanges and then there were some that needed a youtube guide, the game needs some sort of hint system.#2: Puzzle pieces: These should have been a bonus and the levels should have been harder to get to the end of without the colletion of them, some levels were a straight shot to the next level with the pieces in puzzles around you. It was too easy to get through without the pieces and too hard with the pieces.#3: Post game There are 8 stars you need to collect in order to get the second ending. There almost no way someone would just stumble upon a star or know how to get one without looking it up, I bet there are people who went through the whole game and never came back to it completley unaware of these stars. Some require waiting 2 hours others require you to have not completed the game yet. What's that, you have? Only option is to reset all of your effort if you want it. Had it not been for the stars I probably wouldn't have left a negative review but it was so glaringly obvious there was a better ending and I wanted to see it, but I already beat the game so I just looked it up.

If you think you could connect to this story, then consider buying the game, otherwise there's better stuff out there. If I could turn back time would I still buy this game? Probably not. Probably not.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												A nonsensical plot atop a mind-bending puzzle game. I won't describe the plot anymore than saying it does not make any sense and when you think you've got a handle on it, it quickly flies away.As for the gameplay, its pretty damn fun if you're into this kind of puzzle game. By that I mean really hard ones with no hint system whatsoever. You can rewind time, and must use this skill and some platforming to collect jigsaw puzzle pieces. This isn't strictly necessary but, given the terrible storytelling, the puzzles are the only fun this game offers. Oh and the game often adds very interesting wrinkles to this time mechanic. The design is fantastic. But this is also an extremely hard game. There is no smooth difficulty curve. I tried to get each puzzle piece myself and only looked up a solution after reaching peak frustration. I was able to get the majority of them myself, and more than a few times found the solution to be something I never would have thought of.I'm happy to have played Braid, mainly because I wanted to see why critics love it so much. But while the gameplay was definitely novel and very clever, the difficulty felt like poor design to me. (Full disclosure, I'm NOT a fan of very hard games.) And I HATE the story. So I'm glad I got t for cheap in a humble bundle.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Play Length: Less than an hour.  This is just my impression of the game, so you should take it with a bunch of salt.Positives: I generally like the graphics.  The painterly style is kind of nice to look at.  The concept of the puzzle design being about turning back time seems intriguing.Negatives: As far as the gameplay goes, I just couldn't wrap my head around many of the puzzles.  Many of them seemed like I needed to come back later, because I was missing some ability, but I wasn't quite sure.  Unfortunately, I can't comment on the puzzle design with much authority because I just didn't want to play the game very long.What I can say for sure is that this game was off putting for me.  I'll try to put my finger on that... mainly, it's the soundtrack.  I hated it.  Soundtrack is very important to me, especially for a platformer of this style.  But this game's soundtrack is all wrong.  As music, it is nice enough, but as a soundtrack it just doesn't fit what is happening on screen.  It's non congruent.  It's also not particularly good soundtrack music as none of it is very memorable.  It basically sounds like someone just grabbed some random music off their ipod and just through it in background while I played.  I think this non congruency might be why some people accuse this game of pretentious-ness.  To be "pretentious" literally means to put on a pretense of something you're not, and the soundtrack alone sounds like it's screaming at the player "this game is very serious and important!" while not at all trying to fit what was happening on screen.  The very definition of pretentiousness.From what I've heard, this pretentiousness also extends to the story, but unfortunately I can't comment on that.  What I can say is, besides the soundtrack, there was just something about this game that really put me off.  Maybe it was the overall feeling of the game, that feeling that all of the components aren't meshing well together.Overall: I'll be the first to admit that this not a great review.  What a review is supposed to do is inform about a game, and I don't know enough about it to provide much useful information.  If I worked for a gaming publication, I wouldn't publish this.  But you know, I'm just a guy who tried the game, and this is my personal impression of that game.  For me personally, the first hour of playing this game was enough to put me off from wanting to play any more.  Feel free to take that for what you think it's worth.About my rating system: I have two things I rate on.  Overall score, and soundtrack.  Personally, I feel like game soundtracks are tremendously undervalued; to me, it's a vital factor in getting me into the game.  For the score, I grade on a scale of 1-10, and I try to grade in such a way that each number has a meaning and equal importance.  The meaning of each number are as follows:0: Garbage, 1: Awful, 2: Poor, 3: Underwhelming, 4: Mediocre, 5: Decent, 6: Good, 7: Great, 8: Excellent, 9: Phenomenal, 10: MasterpieceBraid's score:Game Rating: 4 (Mediocre)Soundtrack Rating: 1 (Awful)

Posted: February 7, 2014
												Generally this game is fine. Only one DEVASTATING problem: it's too hard. Puzzle games like this should have a good amount of training. You train players until they fully catch one idea of puzzle solving, and only then can you put them into a real puzzle. However this game lacks training - there's hardly any training at all, it just throws you into a brain-killing puzzle and then nothing. As a result, most of the puzzles seem impossible to me, and I've lost all interest in this game.+ beautiful graphic and music+ flawless time reversing+ moving story (from what I've seen so far)- not enough training5 out of 10, unsatisfying.

number of helpful: 14 of 35 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Beautiful game with a charming (albiet mildly incoherent) story. Controls are solid and I appreciate the fact that nothing is explained, instead of the player must figure it out. It's too bad then that the game suffers from such poor design a times. Puzzles can be broken, making the unsolvable and needing a restart. Some puzzles are timed, miss the timing and again, a restart is required as rewinding won't fix it. There is no quick way to do this however, one must either go back to a door and then back to the puzzle, or exit the world, reinter it, and select the level. For a game that requries such trial and error one would assume the game designer would have made this more easily done.Additionally, this game requires 100% completion. You have 5 worlds to start out with, and to get to the next world you must complete every single level before, getting all puzzle pieces is the only way to actually beat the game. Most games that require progression in earlier levels to reach the final destination settle for an amount close to 100%, but not quite. Of course, it wouldn't be as much of an issue if the game didn't suffer from the restart issue described earlier. Sadly this just made the game a chore to play, which isn't much of a game at all at that point.

number of helpful: 13 of 33 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Braid is a puzzle-platformer, drawn in a painterly style, where you can manipulate the flow of time in strange and unusual ways. From a house in the city, journey to a series of worlds and solve puzzles to rescue an abducted princess. In each world, you have a different power to affect the way time behaves, and it is time's strangeness that creates the puzzles. The time behaviors include: the ability to rewind, objects that are immune to being rewound, time that is tied to space, parallel realities, time dilation, and perhaps more. Braid treats your time and attention as precious; there is no filler in this game. Every puzzle shows you something new and interesting about the game world.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I find the time travel mechanic pretty unique, but the game overuses it. I found that all the puzzles were challenging, for me anyway. One of my problems with this game is for those people who aren't really into it for the collecting can sometimes just simply walk right to the exit. I found this games puzzles interesting and creative, using the time travel really well. But some of these are nearly impossible and the fact that i could just walk right past it was really annoying. Take world 2. The ... hedgehogs, I guess, were getting fired out of the cannon and you had to time it perfectley to make it across the gap. I ended up just walking right past it after trying MANY times to make it. And the no dying? Breaks alot of gaming rules. Dying is part of how gaming works. And besides, it's not like it helps you. It takes you back to exactly where you are and for most of it all it helps you with is knowing that you were off by a few seconds. Pretty useless. The game fails to tell you anything about what things do and how they work. I had to figure out how to go back in time which i caught on to at the start of the second world. The story was pretty dull and boring so i really didn't pay attention to the text. The game isn't exciting. The music is bland, the puzzles can be repetitive, the story is boring, the game is confusing, and it's just not that fun.They even started reusing puzzles! I swear, the first world has a parkour to the end level. 2 worlds later, they have the exact same level, but you have to kill all the monsters on your way. Again, the game overuses the time travel. Need to revive, time travel. Kill a boss, time travel. Timed something wrong, time travel. Do anything wrong whatsoever, you guessed it. TIME TRAVEL! To sum it up, this game is probably the worst I currently have on Steam. It's just different for me cause i'm used to sidescrollers to having killing things, platforming, and making to the end of the stage. Not going back in time to solve problems, having optional puzzles on the way, and taking a nice lovely stroll through a bland field and occasionally jumping over a hedgehog. This game gets a 2 out of 5.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Braid... another award winning turd. This game is Everything that every other puzzle platformer isnt. The soudtrack is a dull, plodding, violin based piece garunteed to put even the loudest of colicky babies to sleep. The gameplay is as slow as the soundtrack. The time reversing mechanic is a joke, as no matter what happens you just reverse time to fix it. You died? No problems! Just hold the time reverse button, no matter how long your body has been laying on the bottom of the screen. seriously. you get hit and fall to the bottom of the screen. make it there and all it does is prompt you to hit the time reversal button. there is really no way to "lose" at all, you just play until you get bored.If you're looking for a challenge, or even a fun game, Look elsewhere. If youre looking for an unloseable exercise in boredom, This is the "game" for you!

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I'm just putting negative to counteract the massive unnecessary praise. This game is pretty much pretentious Super Mario Bros. without a time limit. The story, which I had thought was a highlight going into the game, is literally just poorly written flavor text that flashes on the screen before you enter a world, that you couldn't care less about if you tried. The watercolor art and the classical music playing during the levels really showcase the pretentiousness of the devs. Finally, in my opinion, while some of the mechanics were entertaining at first, many of the puzzles are poorly designed and frustrating, even with the somewhat unique time reversal mechanic. Something is wrong in any puzzle game when I am unable to beat a level simply because a mechanic wasn't introduced properly. Yes, of course I believe puzzles should be challenging, but in a much more genuine way. I never had to use the internet for Portal or Portal 2 even for the challenge maps, and yet I always eventually found the solutions out after taking plenty of time scanning my surroundings. With Braid, I had to use the internet on more than three of the puzzles and each time I felt completely ripped off.The bottom line is that Braid just isn't very much fun. If I play it for a while, it sort of grows on me, but once I quit, I can't force myself to go back and play it. It also makes me angry that Jonathan Blow has the audacity to go on record and criticize other, far greater video games than his own, the least of which being Bioshock Infinite. For as many problems as Bioshock Infinite had, it's still a far more entertaining game than Braid.

number of helpful: 28 of 65 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2012
												Braid is a traditional 2D side scrolling platform game that feels very familiar. You enter different levels, hop on most enemies to defeat them, find keys, open doors and climb ladders. It feels very familiar. There is a jump button, up lets you go in doors or climb ladders, and a button for the big twist.The big twist is time manipulation, you can reverse time or fast forward it once you have rewound it. This way, when you die, you rewind time to when you didn't die. You rewind time to help you solve puzzles too.Such as, you will get a key, open a door and find another door, well you can rewind time to where you still had the key. When time is restarted, you will have the key, but the first door will be open. A lot of puzzles are like that in the game, whether its dropping 5 ceiling fixtures onto a boss's head when you need to rewind time to reset the fixtures or grabbing a key in a pit and rewinding time to when you didn't fall in the pit (but still keep the key).The game feels mellow and has a unique art style that makes it feel like a story book. There are things before the levels that you can walk by and read the rich back story to the game.While it is amazingly good, challenging and thought provoking. It feels like other free games found on the Internet. This game is just the best of them all, its a nice change of pace from everything that is 3D in the world.To be honest this game is more challenging than fun. It is a side scrolling platform puzzle game. Like Mario.... but with a tragic story. Like an unhappy Mario game based on puzzles that require you to rewind time, speed it up, slow it down. All that fun stuff. The only catch is that the difficulty curve goes up a giant hill. It is not fun and it gets challenging too quickly all while keeping a sad tone and a painted art style. Skip this game and forget how many people love it because its one of the first indie games to get praise. Go pick up something fun instead.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												As other negative reviews have stated, I found Braid to be a bit pretentious. Just because a game seems deep or philosophical does not automatically mean it's a shining paragon of gaming artistry. The games time reverse gimmick is pretty neat at first, but the schtick wears off pretty quickly as the "puzzle" difficulty ratchets up extremely fast. I thought Braid's artwork was really nice to look at although the main character looked a bit to me like a shrunken down Junior Gorg from Fragil Rock outfitted in a schoolboy uniform. The soundtrack was also a bit off-putting for me, much like the time reverse aspect, the music was nice at first, but I soon found myself turning my speakers off while playing. Finally, the play through time. The one saving grace I found didn't have anything to do with the game at all, it's the fact that I bought Braid during a Steam sale for about 75% off. I finished the game in about 5 hours and would have felt terrible paying full price.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												As with many Indie games, I find Braid is the type which requires you to fail in order to see the path you must take.  You can either opt to sit at a puzzle for what seems like an inordinate amount of time, mentally going through what course of action you'd take (which is difficult, as with the bidirectional nature of time flow in the game) or you can "do as you go", which ultimately ends up in repeated failures in a short amount of time (one of THE worst peeves I have).I don't have much time with Braid, but that's simply because I could not tolerate that game mechanic being the crux of the game's success in my eyes.

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Pure hype.  Just an obnoxiously convoluted puzzle game.  And I love puzzle games, but come on.  This has a lot of those obnoxious point-and-click tropes, where they have "cleverly" (read "annoyingly" to anyone whose confidence in their own intelligence doesn't need to be reinforced by figuring out infuriatingly contrived puzzles) hidden things that seem like part of the backdrop, and make them necessary elements of gameplay.  There is also no instruction to guide you, and tell you things such as "the further you drop onto an enemy, the further you bounce back up", which is QUENTESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE for completing THE FIRST DAMN WORLD.  And while I understand that at least SOME people enjoy the point and click elements, because it makes them feel smart when they find them, I don't think anyone enjoys sitting around for two hours, trying to desperately realize things such as the long drop onto an enemy = high bounce.  That should be part of the game's nonexistent tutorial.Anyone who calls this "fun" probably just needs to see a shrink about their confidence in their own intelligence.  I can't possibly see why anyone would put up with the level of shenanigans this game brings, unless they DESPERATELY, PAINFULLY needed to feel better about how smart they were.Meanwhile, me and my friends, most of whom consider themselves intellectuals, found this game to be very dull and trite.  For all the internet hype around this game, nobody I personally know enjoyed it.  Just goes to show you, you buy enough good reviews from the right people, or get the right person as your fanboy, and you can have just all kinds of undeserved money and praise.

number of helpful: 7 of 22 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Braid is an ugly, pretentious thing. As a game, it's a VERY standard (and probably sub-standard, given its length) platformer/puzzle game with some time gimmicks. The puzzles themselves mostly aren't very difficult, with more issues arising from implementing your solution rather than thinking it up due to the way it controls. If Braid were just about this, it'd be pretty okay for, say, an internet flash game. Graphically, the game is... not nearly as good as it is hyped up to be. Eye-wateringly bright colour palettes (world 3 is especially bad about this) and largely boring environments mark this as ugly and forgettable. Musically, for my taste nothing really stood out at all. Writing this after having just beaten the game, I'm already having trouble remembering most of the pieces.Where the game really starts to stink is its story, which is 90% delivered to you in horrible prose dumps. The writing in these is absolutely excruciating and later often only tangentially related to the levels you experience afterward. Video game 'academics' have stated that this game manages to meld story and gameplay: I fail to see it. At any rate, the provision of story via a gigantic ugly text dump at the beginning of a world is a major design disaster and, for me, a sign of the game being supremely self-conscious about presenting itself as an intellectual experience (it fails).Please, video games, stop trying to be 'art'.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												I have tried playing this game quite a number of times, but each time I end up quitting because of several reasons.- I despise the art style. This is purely a preference, but it drives me crazy. I also don't like the main character guy. I just don't.- I don't understand why there are enemies at all in the game. You literally can't lose no matter how many times you die, so why bother putting annoying enemies that add nothing to the game? I don't get it.- I have gotten stuck in spots where there is an enemy on top of a ladder, and it is the only way to move forward. The only way out is to quit the level.- I found the level selection area to be confusing and have no idea how it works at all.- The puzzle pieces don't add anything to the game. If I wanted to solve a very simple puzzle, I would get one of my little sister's.- A lot of the puzzles aren't solved by clever thinking, but instead by randomly moving backward and forward in time repeatedly until you get the timing exactly perfect to make a jump. This may be fun for some people, but i would prefer something more clever.

Posted: December 3, 2011
												Wouldn’t it be awesome if you had the power to cheat death and manipulate time to undo or redo your consequences? Braid offers just that with beautiful paint drawn visuals where you can manipulate the flow of time. At first you might say that the game feels a little like Super Mario but it is not. Each world has its own puzzle strategy on how you manipulate time because they’re all different from each other. The selection of music soundtrack that is used in this game is just brilliant. If you like platformer puzzle adventure game with an interesting plot story twist that will have you say “Holy crap! I didn’t see that coming!” then, you should really give Braid a shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 18
First things first: The game mechanics are phenomenal, giving new time-travelling challenges and ways of solving puzzles that I never thought I’d see in a game. If you are looking for a heavy brain workout, look no further. This experience will stay with me for the longest time for sure (so much so that I unwittingly tried to rewind time in other games as well. *disappointed much* Which threw me back to a post-Life-is-Strange era). Even though this game has earned a huge thumbs up for me, it definitely has some drawbacks.Downsides: - The not-so-precise jumping controls and the timing of some puzzles can be a real pain. Sometimes you have a puzzle figured out pretty quickly… in theory. But you spend the next 10 minutes rewinding and dying, rewinding and dying like a maniac, getting a tiny bit more frustrated every single time. - I had heard great things about ‘the twist’ of the story. Well, after finishing the game and finding said twist I had to look up the meaning of it all. There can be many interpretations. - No explanations of the mechanics in all the worlds. This can be interpreted as a positive challenge however.Conclusion:Even though you can die hundreds of times in the game (and at the same time the game won’t ever let you really die), and some levels can be a drag, the good things most certainly outweigh the bad. The groundbreaking mechanics were all I needed to stamp this game as a massive success and I’m happy I took the gamble of checking it out. Le spoilers:Parts that I LOVED:  Creating a shadow version of myself, strangely giving some puzzles a co-op vibe :D Parts that I HATED:  Those green sparking little brown furball basterds stealing your keys. Or when you have to guide them to safety like a couple of suicidal ‘special’ lemmings. Or the key that just keeps escaping... if you’ve played the game you know the one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Gameplay 5/5: A Mario-inspired puzzle platformer with a rewind mechanic that changes enough from world to world to stay fresh, but always remains intuitive.  Creative puzzle design makes the most of the game mechanics to require both clever thinking and precision maneuvering.Art 2/2: Beautifully designed worlds, backgrounds with multiple layers of depth, and a score of gorgeous Celtic folk string compositions that distort along with time make this game atmospherically engaging as its gameplay.Story 1.25/2: The elements of the story are creative, but are divulged in an overwrought and cryptic manner that is more pretentious than poetic.Technical Support .25/1: Game is forced in 1280x720 fullscreen mode.  Supports XBox 360 controllers and keyboard, but   no support for other controllers or rebinding keys.  The keyboard controls also lose the unique buttons for using doors or the magic ring, making any workaround with Joy2Key or Xpadder imperfect.Total 8.5/10: Minor problems can't detract from what is one of the most beautiful indie games to date.  Highly recommended.

												A game with a somewhat confusing storyline and interesting puzzles. The levels are really well made and the gameplay is varied, allowing the player to rewind your actions and manipulate time to achieve incredible and really fun results.That said, it's a game to very pacient players who really like to think. Some puzzles are incredbly complicated, specially if you want to get all the collectables (it gives you a different ending). The stars are painful to get and you don't even know that there are stars to collect to begin with unless you're really, REALLY creative (or read a walkthrough, as I did). I don't have this pacience; I had to watch videos to be able to finish it. But if you're a puzzle fan, this game definitively deserves a shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												"Super mario meets Doctor who"This is my initial thought when I start to play this game. Braid is a platformer like many games, but with a gentle touch on the shift key you reverse the flow of time. This enables some really nifty features which is foundation for some really tough puzzles.  And I mean tough, becuse you can probably fix the tardis if you can solve them straight away. The game is divided into six worlds where each one adds a new mechanic to keep the gameplay refreshing.   Visually, it's like playing an oil painting. It's colorful and clear. Level parts and vackground mix together in a beautiful result.The soundtrack is brilliant. A calming crossover between folk and classical that sets your brain to a mysterious thinking mode.Epic and soothing, the music is also intgrated in the gameplay in a really smart way (time goes backwards, music plays backwards). So the verdict. Should you buy this? Well, the game is not perfect. Being somewhat short (playthrough around two to three hours) and having a limited replay value is some major setbacks but the good sides greatly makes up for the less perfect sides. Hey, if you want a great puzzle game that really tests your thinking, get this (or atleast consider buying it).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												This game is absolutely amazing. The art, the music, and especially the narrative. In 2007 when Braid was first released on the Xbox store, it gained mass popularity, and I never really understood why, until now, after seeing the fantastic ending. Before seeing the ending, I thought it was okay, but not deserving the popularity it had. But the ending is a massive twist, and presented amazingly well. I won't spoil it, I urge you to play this game and see it for yourself. It is definitely worth finishing one of the most difficult puzzle games I have ever played for this ending. It's a great end to all the effort put in. Really.The game's controls were very creative, I loved being able to manipulate time. The controls (forgetting about the epic twist at the end) brought a lovely fresh of breath air to the cliche story of 'catch a princess'.The game is a puzzle-platformer, and it's puzzles were good. Extremely good. Each puzzle took me quite a while to finally solve, and they were each very clever. The layout of the levels makes it seem like they are easy to solve, but in reality, each level takes about 30+ minutes to solve each. Each world brought new game mechanics, and taught each mechanic very subtlely, and not in your face. Some of the puzzles were re used, but the change in game mechanics changed the re used levels almost completely. For example, there was a world 3 level used in world 6, but because of the different game mechanics, it was much, much harder to solve in world 6. Some people dislike the re-use of levels, but I, personally, liked it. I think it's cool to see how different game mechanics work on the same levels. Also, the reused levels were used as mechanic tutorials, making the player think "Ahh! Well I've done this before, so I can do it again easily", before realising that they can't solve the puzzle the same way due to different mechanics. As I said before, very clever.The games graphics and sound track were utterly beautiful. I love the comic book style the game has, it looks amazing. The classic music style matches the theme of the game perfectly. However, I would have prefered a couple visuals to go along with the storybook narration. I think the lack of visuals whilst being given a narrative is a turn-off for some people, myself included. This is a shame, since the story is sensational. I give this game a 8/10, missing two marks solely because of the lack of visuals during narration. Easily reccommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												What can I say about Braid! The only word I can think of, is amazing. Braid is a work of art, in terms of audio/visuals and story and level design. This game is truly the best Indy title in my opinion. You play as Tim, the main character trying to rescue his princess. To do so, you must collect puzzle pieces, which are scattered throughout the levels. Each level is a puzzle to solve, some are very easy in the early levels, and as you progress, elements are introduced that make it harder, such as controlling time, world objects, and whatnot. The audio is the best part aside from the visuals and story. The music is just so well done, audio effects are cute too. The visuals look like hand painted water color images, and animation is top notch. The developers really put their time and energy into making this game. There are many hidden things to discover, and to fully beat the game, will take some time because of the one element you collect (stars) can be SO HARD you might need a guide. I love this game, it is well worth the money and I keep playing it over and over. With speed runs, and pieces to collect, beautiful story and visuals and audio, Braid will captivate you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												I remember looking this game up before buying it. The game, and seemingly its developer, takes itself way too seriously. The game, as well as its advertising, seemed to be full of the worst kind of indie pretension: the one that judges everything else to be crap, and seems to pass judgement on those who complacently consume said mediocrity. Braid touted itself as an experience in a league entirely of its own, that the big bad AAA titles could not touch.And, wouldn't you know it, as much as I hate to admit it, they were absolutely 100% right. Braid is in a league of its own. It makes almost every other puzzle game in existence seem cheap, insipid, repetitive, uninspired. I think it's most incredible feat is that, while it is far from easy by any means, it is neither complex nor is it frustrating. I've never seen another puzzle game achieve this most delicate of balances.Every puzzle is delightfully simple, requiring you to discover some novel new use of the mechanics you've learned so far. You are not expected to pick apart intricate constructions, and spam a few techniques you've applied dozens of times already until the solution falls out. No, for practically every puzzle in Braid, you will do something new, something you haven't yet considered. And when the solution does fall out, it's often beautiful, and you will feel AMAZING.Speaking of beauty, the whole game is extraordinarily beautiful. The music, the art, the story, the puzzles: all of them are exquisite. Looking at screenshots does not do the game's artwork justice, as the backgrounds shift and breathe in a most serene yet breathtaking manner.Basically, this game ends whatever remnants of the "Are video games art?" discussion. In every conceivable way, this game is a master-class in game design. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Braid, my favorite puzzler-platformer, and the game I think of when I try to remember how I stumbled upon Steam in the first place. [No... I didn't actually play it on steam, to be honest, I was in college and torrented the game(most likely illegally) and have since purchased it because it think it was worth way more to me than most of the crap titles I buy on here because of their low prices or the fact that they're in a humble bundle.]That was pointless info... anyway, the story is one of love and loss and time travel and although it lacks realism in its time traveling logic, it does so purposefully. It's fun without worrying so much about overbearing details in the storyline, perhaps because of the dreamlike tone of the game, and the art style choices for the rewind and overlapping abilities. Its extremely fun, I mean I beat the game 100% without even having the incentive of steam achievements, and I am tempted to play through again because of how easily the game coaxes the player from the opening scene to the end (and vice versa heheh) without feeling any lag or down points where one might think "Eh, now's a good stopping point, i'll play it later."Easily, this game was worth $10 to me, and although I hate absolution in practice, I have to give this game a 10/10. You could sit here and poke holes in it all day and none of your complaints would lower my experience with the game, i'm giving it a perfect score because there's nothing more or less I wanted out of it. Awesome story, awesome gameplay, awesome length, and awesome overall tone/experience.Overall: 10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												On the surface, Braid is a simple puzzle platformer. The gameplay, at its most basic level, consists of jumping on platforms and collecting puzzle pieces before moving to the next world. A couple of things set Braid apart and make it a fantastic experience. The first is the visuals. Everything in Braid is hand drawn, and it's quite a pleasure to progress through the game and see the different landscapes. Second; the puzzles. The puzzles in the latter stages of the game are, to say the least, mind-bending. You will have difficulty getting through Braid without a walkthrough for at least a couple of levels. Braid is best played in short burts; play for too long and the harder puzzles get frustrating. The puzzles themselves are brilliantly designed and are very satisfying to solve. The main gimmick of Braid is the ability to manipulate (reverse) time. It adds another dimension to puzzle solving and forces you to think about puzzles in abstract ways. Truthfully, Braid isn't for everyone, but it offers a unique gameplay experience for the puzzler fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 11
												Braid is a brilliant and innovative 2D puzzle platformer.The main character has the power to rewind time and this is used in novel ways in almost all the puzzles. Additionally, each world has a unique mechanic that alters the gameplay in one way or another.The puzzles themselves are typically quite clever and well-designed. The first few worlds are reasonably easy, but the difficulty ramps up pretty quickly and by the end of the game you are facing puzzles that feel nearly impossible until you figure them out.The hand-drawn art is gorgeous and the beautiful soundtrack is a great fit for the game too. The only thing I didn't particularly like was the rather pretentious story.Overall Braid is one of the best puzzle games ever made and easy to recommend to any fans of the genre. However, the game does have some rather difficult puzzles, so if you are not very good at puzzle solving Braid can get rather tedious and frustrating.I did get stuck on a couple of puzzles for a while, but in general the difficulty level was pretty much spot on for me.The good:- Innovative time manipulation mechanics- Clever and well-designed puzzles- Gorgeous hand-drawn art- Nice soundtrack- Good level of challengeThe bad:- Pretentious story and writing

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												Braid is a puzzle platformer.You play as Tim, a guy attempting to rescue his princess from a monster. You explore 6 worlds, each with several levels filled with puzzles. You solve puzzles using a time manipulation mechanics, which are enhanced the further you go in the game. Levels also feature hidden collectibles which unlock more of the story.The puzzles are clever and really engaging. It is so fulfilling when you finally figure out what it is you need to do. I think that the puzzles are made to be engaging but not so obscure that you will never work out the answer without help...although that is my opinion.The levels themselves look so beautiful and gorgeous...I have actually spent time just waltzing through the levels alone and admiring the art and music.The game seems to draw on many aspects of gaming and comes into its own when you look at the game and its plot from a philosophical standpoint. It really makes you think and encourages you to do so.Replayability is limited though...even with the beautiful art and music. Once you complete the levels, find the hidden collctibles and see the ending, there isn't much to keep doing. The time trials extend replayability slightly, but not everyone likes time trials.Despite this, I still think this is a game worth getting and playing for any gamer.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game has a lot going for it-- a deep story, pretty graphics, some of the best music, and great gameplay.The story is not at all forced. There are several books lined up at the start of each world, and you can just run right past them without even reading them if you like. However, if you go deeper, you discover just how thorough the story is. Check the internet if you can't figure it out, because I don't want to spoil it. It'll blow your mind.The game allows you to rewind time, so even if you fall to your death, you can undo it. It allows you to mess up and know you messed up, but then it doesn't take away the last five minutes of your life by making you redo the level and re-obtain what you got. That's a daring move, but it works for a game like this.Braid is an experience. There are few games that aren't just fun but also artistic and mind-blowing. Braid is the few.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												A short classic indie side-scroller platform/puzzle game. I typically find side-scrollers too strenous, but this one really hit the correct balance of challenge and forgiveness. The story is nice enough, but I really enjoyed the puzzle aspect more which relies on playing with the passage of time. Even after completing the main storyline you can go back and collect puzzle pieces to open up and understand more of the plot - though be advised that it was designed to be an open ended device so don't expect resolution. I would NOT recommend this game if: 1) An open-ended/interpretative story/ending is frustrating to you. 2) You are looking for a hardcore/bulletstorm-type of side-scroller.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2013
												An old Cherokee sits down with his grandson to ruminate on life. THe young boy looks up from his smartphone and says, "Grandpa, there are two metaphors for modern humanity's virtualization, one is as follows:--------AN old projectionist was talking with a protege, watching the film tick past the lamp during a late screening."In your mind there are two reels. The first is a film of pleasure, love and grace.  THe other is the sadness and loss in the world. Both are fighting to be digitized before they fall apart. "" But sir, which one gets saved?""The one you feed."--------The other goes like this:--------A young startup CEO talks with his mentor venture capitalist over coffee ."There are two social networks at war within the human body", says the mentor, "the nervous system which makes you fear people , and the reproductive system that makes you do them. Life is the app that reads the updates.""But sir, then what are we?""THe feed who won."--------The old Cherokee turns to his grandson, " But child, which is best?""The one you read."

												The game is very well made and will challenge you to think differently about how you play a platformer and about how you think of time. The art style is this games stongest element. Every single frame is pretty enough to hang on a wall. You will have fun playing this game and its so beautiful that your eyes will bleed rain bows.The "story" however is another matter. Many of the other reviews talk about how deep the story is, im wondering what story that is because i didn't really notice much of a story at all. Other than a general sense of guilt and how nice it would be to undo mistake the narrative doesn't really give you much. MAny critics have praised how many interpritations there are to the narrative, real watercooler type discussions, but i cant help bu feel that the only reason this game has so many interpritations is because the game never tells you what its about, you need to fill in the very large story blanks with your own imaginaiton and interpritaiton.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I'm very late to the party when it comes to reviewing Braid, but nonetheless, here we go.Braid is a very interesting puzzle/platformer, in which you can control the flow of time. This means that you can change if you're going forwards or backwards on the stage with the flow of time itself. I'm not too good at explaining it, but this is something you'll be able to experience by playing the game. The controls are simple: Left, Right, Space (Jump) and Shift (time control). Because the controls are simple, a lot of work has been put into the puzzles and the levels, which were a pleasure to play through.In terms of art style, Braid feels very hand drawn, but professionally so, and is total eye-candy (probably why I died a few times to the enemies). As for the soundtrack, it's ear-candy. Basically, this game is candy, which you can't eat, otherwise you'd break your laptop or computer.Figuring out the puzzles can be a little challenging at first, and admittedly I got frustrated at them, so maybe an option for hints would have been nice, but I understand why this wasn't included. I can't really say too much else about the game to be honest (at least not without spoiling it) so I'll leave it there.Braid gets a 9/10 from me, and if you haven't already, play this game.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2011
												Irrespective of what your preconceived notions are of Braid, it is one of the best puzzle adventures you will ever play. The mind melting puzzles are very challenging at times, and keep you constantly changing the way you approach them.  The diverse puzzles are filet mignon, and the gorgeous environments and sweeping score are the fine wine. The backgrounds pulse and shimmer as if they were alive, and it is all underscored by relaxing violin pieces. But all this wasn't what impressed me the most, no. What really made me fall in love with this game is the incredibly thought provoking storyline. What if all you fought and strived for was turned against you? What would you do and how would you feel? The story of Tim trying to save the princess is a metaphor for something much, much deeper. When I finished the final puzzle and saw the ending it blew me away. Simply amazing. This is not an action game, so if you're looking to blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up this isn't for you. I've gushed enough! 10/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												So, the way I found out about this game is that a hipster friend of mine got very very drunk a couple of years back and told me I just HAD to download this on PSN. I never took him for the gamer type, and to humor his drunk opinion I figured why not. I wasn't disappointed.Now here's the thing. This game isn't challenging. At all. It's pretty reasonable to be able to see all of the content on your first play through. There are some pretty clever spots that might stick folks for a little bit, but this game is in no way difficult.This is a beauty to see though. The story and the art direction are what make this game worth having in your collection. The game play is puzzle Mario-ish at best, but the attention to detail is what will stick with you after playing this.If you're looking for something calm and purposeful inbetween alien/zombie gore fests, this could be right up your alley. I would say that the story is something better appreicated by some one with some years on them. Probably 25 plus. It's not inappropriate for a younger audience, it's just the kind of plot that is more impactful if the player has had a good number of experiences in life.

												Braid is a great game for the money. Braid contains a different variety of challenging puzzles which can make your brain melt, the game contains time elements so you can go back to the past and do something different to what you did previously which adds so many more elements to the game. Braid's graphics are retro, but in a good way giving it a Mario like feel. The only issue I have with Braid is that it's very easy to just run through the game without solving the puzzles which are the most difficult and gives you far less motivation to complete them when you know that you can just skip them.If you enjoy puzzles and want to try something different from the usual, Braid just may be the game for you.

Posted: August 27, 2013
												An old Cherokee sits down with his grandson to ruminate on life. THe young boy looks up from his smartphone and says, "Grandpa, there are two metaphors for modern humanity's virtualization, one is as follows:--------AN old projectionist was talking with a protege, watching the film tick past the lamp during a late screening."In your mind there are two reels. The first is a film of pleasure, love and grace.  THe other is the sadness and loss in the world. Both are fighting to be digitized before they fall apart. "" But sir, which one gets saved?""The one you feed."--------The other goes like this:--------A young startup CEO talks with his mentor venture capitalist over coffee ."There are two social networks at war within the human body", says the mentor, "the nervous system which makes you fear people , and the reproductive system that makes you do them. Life is the app that reads the updates.""But sir, then what are we?""THe feed who won."--------The old Cherokee turns to his grandson, " But child, which is best?""The one you read."

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												On the surface, Braid is a simple puzzle platformer. The gameplay, at its most basic level, consists of jumping on platforms and collecting puzzle pieces before moving to the next world. A couple of things set Braid apart and make it a fantastic experience. The first is the visuals. Everything in Braid is hand drawn, and it's quite a pleasure to progress through the game and see the different landscapes. Second; the puzzles. The puzzles in the latter stages of the game are, to say the least, mind-bending. You will have difficulty getting through Braid without a walkthrough for at least a couple of levels. Braid is best played in short burts; play for too long and the harder puzzles get frustrating. The puzzles themselves are brilliantly designed and are very satisfying to solve. The main gimmick of Braid is the ability to manipulate (reverse) time. It adds another dimension to puzzle solving and forces you to think about puzzles in abstract ways. Truthfully, Braid isn't for everyone, but it offers a unique gameplay experience for the puzzler fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Braid is a perfect example of how to take something good and make it better. The classic platformer has been around since before Super Mario Bros., and Number None has made their own wonderfully puzzling take on the genre. Braid will make you think in ways you would never expect. In each section of the game you play with time as you platform, and in each section there is a new obstacle/method to master. The story is intruiging as it is mysterious, the gameplay is smooth and intuitive, and the mechanics are mind-bending in the best way possible. Braid is a new take on an old classic and it deserves its spot as a treasure amidst Indie games. It may not provide the same experience that a AAA title may be able to achieve, but it more than makes up for any lack of fancy graphics and massive world with its creativity and uniqueness. Try out Braid if you want a challenge, just make sure you prepare to be surprised.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This is one of the most complex yet seemingly simple platforming puzzle games I've ever played. The non-linear gameplay mechanics are rather unique, and made this experience one to remember. On the surface, 'Braid' seems like a relatively straight forward Mario knock-off with an art house vibe, but as you delve further into this brilliant game, the vibrant visuals and moving music convey an emotional theme with deeper meaning than you initially realize. There is a story at work, told in interactive metaphor, but you have to play it for yourself to fully understand.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Pretty incredible experience packed into a compact game. The focus, and the reward, is how the story itself is told simultaneously by reading through pages on-screen as well as discovering time-bending gameplay mechanics. You might think "Oh I've played with rewind features in Prince of Persia", but Braid is at its best when you as the user step back and wonder what it really means to rewind time. Are all thing turned back perfectly, giving you a second chance, or maybe somethings are outside of your control. Perhaps a mere shadow of yourself survives, or are you the shadow of a now future self? Maybe you shouldn't have tried messing with time in the first place.9/10

Posted: March 11
												Starting positively, there's nice music and really creative art. Also, the integration of puzzles, mechanic, and storytelling are really novel.All that said, gameplay boils down to the "guess what the developer was thinking" kind of puzzle that can only be beaten by either looking up the solution or experimenting wildly until something clicks - neither of which is a puzzle game that I enjoy. Moreover, the "rewind" mechanic gets really annoying really quickly - especially given that it's a "feature" and fundamental to solving so many of these utterly counter-intuitive puzzles.If you like the "guess until you give up or stumble onto a solution" kind of game, enjoy. Otherwise, look elsewhere.

Posted: April 13, 2011
												As far as puzzle platformers go this game is very competent if a little frustrating at times but in a good way.  Me, I love lateral thinking problems, riddles, and puzzles so I couldn't wait to try it; plus the artsy style of the game was a refreshing world to be in for a while.  However, the music and sound will become annoying over time and combined with the annoying enemies WILL produce headaches.  So, just turn on your MP3 player and you're good to go.  If you want something to tie you over until Portal 2 then check it out.  It's been a while since anything has made me think this hard to the point that my brain actually felt tired by the end of the day.  I really enjoyed it, but I'm the kind of person who thinks sitting on my bed on a Friday night brainstorming ideas for puzzles and traps for a D&D dungeon is a wild Friday night.  For hardcore puzzle gamers only.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												This is the definitive puzzle game of the modern times. At the same time nostalgic and something you've never played before. The best thing about Braid is that it actually changes the way you think as the game progresses. Bit by bit the tweaking of time and the problems that come with it start to feel more and more intuitive and you get many moments where you get this strong sense of "heureka, I got it!". Very enjoyable and rewarding experience. In this sense Braid reminds me a lot of Portal series which I can also recommend. If you are into logic puzzles and are not afraid of challenges, you should give Braid a chance. Most likely you won't be disappointed.

												Braid its a game with a nice story that makes you think about yourself, there are themes like Sorrow, Regret, Forgiveness and Force of will. The bad part about it's story in my point, is the endding that's almost impossible for you to understand if you don't read about it online. The gameplay part it surpriseling fun, the backward rewind mechanic that changes in every level (that helps making the game change since there aren't many enemies you change the way you interact with time) makes the game both challenging and fun. The art in it it's quite beautiful also, the soundtrack is kind of nice, i don't like much the desing of the enemies, but overall it's  good game worth buying.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												Braid is an astonishing love letter to the medium of videogames.  It simultaneously resituates the Mario-style 2D platformer and challenges genre conventions with contemporary takes of common tropes like "dying" and "lives" and so on.The art is gorgeous and vibrant, and the occasional personal background touch or oddly out-of-place applique lend an air of legitimacy to the title, preventing it from being a by-the-numbers tileset of levels.  The music is pulled from varying classically-trained artists and perfectly juxtaposes the peaceful, but engaging gameplay.At its heart, the puzzle-platforming is brought to perfection, with mechanics that are devious as well as delightful.  You will use your brain.  You will hurt your brain.  And at the end of it all, you'll walk away from an adventure that will leave you in awe.

The puzzles in this game are so complicated it makes my brain hurt! I admit I became stuck and have not yet gone back to this game to try again.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												For a tenner on Steam, I downloaded Braid and set about discovering the most challenging platform game I’ve come across so far.  Despite no puzzle piece eluding me for more than a few hours, I call it the most challenging because, not only is the process of completing it a good challenge, but the story itself is mostly abstract.  Until we reach what seems to be the end, at least.  That feeling of revelation is rare – I’d recommend it to anyone.  The gameplay will twist your mind in places and if you hunt the stars without assistance, you'll feel like a king.  If you like movies that challenge you, and want something a bit different, get this.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2012
												A game deserving of way more praise than it receives, which in itself is a lot, so you can imagine how highly I recommend it. It's not too long, it can be frustratingly difficult, but it's a puzzle game, you don't want easy.The time manipulation mechanics in this game are superbly thought out and put to good use. It's rare to see a game develop a relatively original concept, stretch it to its limits, and build a game around it so beautifully. Add to that a soundtrack that is delightful and fresh, a rather bizarre storyline (which, to be honest, is not the driver in the game), and you have a good few hours of fun and enjoyment. If you're into platformers and puzzles this is for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2011
												Braid is an incredibly hyped game, and one of the few that I think really deserves it. This game was revolutionary in its time.Braid is a basic puzzle/platformer with an interesting philosophy: instead of punishing players for making mistakes, reward them for the lessons they learn. You get a variety of time-based powers, the most basic of which is to reverse time, allowing you to undo any bad move. But, this concept is explored very creatively. In one world, time is reversed by moving left and moves forward when you move right. In another, you can slow time down, but only for certain parts of the screen.Some of the puzzles are very hard. I remember using a walkthrough for one or two of them.Braid's story is an interesting metaphor that is delivered very well. It starts with a Mario-esque story, but the metaphor's depth is revealed by the end. The art and music are lovely.Absolutely worth it for $10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Very well done puzzle game. Can get very tricky at points, but I like that in a game sometimes. It isn't just a gimme. The infinite rewind is a defining feature of the game, which is what makes it unique. The game forces you to manipulate time in order to earn some of the more difficult to reach puzzle pieces. I did experience some stability issues at first. The game crashed on me several times. The game does have an auto-save feature, which came in very handy every time it crashed. I was able to reboot and pick up exactly where I left off. The crashing issues seemed to have tapered off as I get deeper into the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Puzzle platformers tend to be platform games with a few easy puzzles. Braid is a puzzle games with some easy platform elements. The puzzle mechanic is one of the most innovative I have seen. It involves time manipulation and challenges you to think in new ways to predict the consequences of manipulating time in various ways and use this ability to achieve your goals. It starts out easy and the difficulty ramps up at a good pace. Towards the end the game is challenging even for experienced puzzle solvers. The game is also non-linear in that you don't need to solve everything in one part of the game to progress to later parts, if you get stuck on a puzzle you can go somewhere else and come back to tackle that puzzle later.The game has an artistic style that feels completely natural and fits well with the unique style of the gameplay. Graphics and sound contribute further to make the game atmospheric. The story is told in various ways, including texts you can read at the start of each level but also, in a way, through the pictures that you need to assemble to complete a level.All in all this is the best puzzle platformer I have played (unless you count Portal as a 3D puzzle platformer) and highly recommended to anyone who likes puzzle games.
