content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Braid is.. well. It's hard to describe. Mechanics wise, it's a simple platformer with an interesting gimmick. You can rewind time. The game takes place across six worlds, each with its own additional time manipulating mechanic. Some of the levels can get pretty tough, and I ended up resorting to a walkthrough to solve at least two of the levels (I'm not proud). Braid's a neat little game with a really cool soundtrack, but much of Braid is best explained through experience. Try it out. You might like it. The game took me about 5 hours to complete, and offered a good amount of content for the price. Overall, I'd give it a 8/10.(Note: I got the game on sale for about $1.50. I wouldn't pay more than three bucks for this, but I'm cheap. Get it on a sale. You'll like it.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Braid is my gold standard for puzzle design in video games. It introduces a simple concept - most of the puzzles in Braid revolve around time manipulation. You have control of a character and also control over of the flow of time in that character's world. It throws a few puzzles at you that require understanding of these concepts. It starts simple and then elaborates. Each stage tests your understanding of the previous stage's mechanics and also adds in a new layer of complexity. As an avid gamer, as a programmer, and especially as a fan of puzzle games, I'm usually able to learn and understand game systems very quickly. In most puzzle games, it's usually fairly easy for me to figure out where the game wants me to go, what it wants me to do and how I'm supposed to do it. There were a few puzzles in Braid where I just stared at the TV screen for minutes, just trying to comprehend the complex game systems that were being layered to create Braid's sublime puzzles. Braid's puzzles are completely mind bending, but in the best way. It feels great when a solution clicks and you finally figure out what you're supposed to do. And it boggles my mind even more to think how the developer came up with these puzzles.Braid's levels are divided up into 5 short worlds. Each world introduces and elaborates on a new puzzle solving mechanic. For instance the first world, which is labeled world 2 for some reason, simply introduces character movement and the rewind time mechanic. You can move left and right on a 2d plane and jump just like a platformer. Then it teaches you that you can rewind time to undo your actions Prince of Persia style. This can of course be used to cheat death and undo platforming mistakes you make. You'll need to collect all of the puzzle pieces in each world to unlock final world in Braid. Puzzle pieces are always obviously placed, but difficult to obtain. They are frequently placed behind locked doors or put up high in the air and its up to the player to figure out how to obtain them, which requires a good understanding of the game's time mechanics. A heads up though - the first world is home to my least favorite puzzle in the game. Anyone who has played Braid before knows the one I'm talking about. The solution is kind of ridiculous and out of place with the rest of Braid's excellent puzzle design. You're not wrong for looking up the solution for how to get all of the first world's puzzle pieces.The second world introduces objects that have a green glow on their outline. With these objects, their physical position and movement is completely unaffected by the flow of time. This concept can be trickier than you would think. In the third world, the flow of time is directly tied to your character's physical position. As you move forward, time advances. As you walk backward, time rewinds. This idea is then combined with the second world's mechanics to create some really mind bending puzzles. The fourth and fifth worlds are similar, both introducing new mechanics and combining them with concepts from previous worlds. The fifth world especially is home to some really excellent and difficult problems.Where Braid falters a bit is with its story. It's presented by reading short bits of text that are found before each level. The narrative feels very abstract and artsy. There's not a clear sense of who the main character is or what he's struggling with. There's something about the main character and a princess he's in love with or used to be in love with or something, I don't know. It's so unclear and "open to interpretation". I still can't decide if the ending to this game makes any sense or not. I kind of don't think it does. It feels like the developer may have had some message or theme he wanted to communicate to the player, but Braid failed to connect with me on a narrative level.Overall though, Braid is a good demonstration of excellent game and puzzle design. Aside from that one stupid puzzle in the first world, I've never been so impressed by creative ideas mixed with well thought out design. It's a bit short and the story is kind of nonsense, but Braid more than makes up for that with its sublime puzzles. If you like these types of problem solving games, Braid is absolutely a must play. The Witness, Jonathan Blow's next game, should be out in the coming months. It's definitely my most anticipated game of 2014 and I'm hopeful it'll be as well made as Braid. Expect a post on it later this year.For more video game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												On the surface, Braid is a simple puzzle platformer. The gameplay, at its most basic level, consists of jumping on platforms and collecting puzzle pieces before moving to the next world. A couple of things set Braid apart and make it a fantastic experience. The first is the visuals. Everything in Braid is hand drawn, and it's quite a pleasure to progress through the game and see the different landscapes. Second; the puzzles. The puzzles in the latter stages of the game are, to say the least, mind-bending. You will have difficulty getting through Braid without a walkthrough for at least a couple of levels. Braid is best played in short burts; play for too long and the harder puzzles get frustrating. The puzzles themselves are brilliantly designed and are very satisfying to solve. The main gimmick of Braid is the ability to manipulate (reverse) time. It adds another dimension to puzzle solving and forces you to think about puzzles in abstract ways. Truthfully, Braid isn't for everyone, but it offers a unique gameplay experience for the puzzler fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Braid is a perfect example of how to take something good and make it better. The classic platformer has been around since before Super Mario Bros., and Number None has made their own wonderfully puzzling take on the genre. Braid will make you think in ways you would never expect. In each section of the game you play with time as you platform, and in each section there is a new obstacle/method to master. The story is intruiging as it is mysterious, the gameplay is smooth and intuitive, and the mechanics are mind-bending in the best way possible. Braid is a new take on an old classic and it deserves its spot as a treasure amidst Indie games. It may not provide the same experience that a AAA title may be able to achieve, but it more than makes up for any lack of fancy graphics and massive world with its creativity and uniqueness. Try out Braid if you want a challenge, just make sure you prepare to be surprised.

												As far as puzzle platformers go this game is very competent if a little frustrating at times but in a good way.  Me, I love lateral thinking problems, riddles, and puzzles so I couldn't wait to try it; plus the artsy style of the game was a refreshing world to be in for a while.  However, the music and sound will become annoying over time and combined with the annoying enemies WILL produce headaches.  So, just turn on your MP3 player and you're good to go.  If you want something to tie you over until Portal 2 then check it out.  It's been a while since anything has made me think this hard to the point that my brain actually felt tired by the end of the day.  I really enjoyed it, but I'm the kind of person who thinks sitting on my bed on a Friday night brainstorming ideas for puzzles and traps for a D&D dungeon is a wild Friday night.  For hardcore puzzle gamers only.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												If Braid is in your backlog and you're looking for something to do on Saturday afternoon, give it a playthrough.  It will only take a few hours and you won't regret a moment of it.+ Gameplay - Interesting mechanics executed well.  The game just feels good to play.  I enjoyed it so much that I played through the game a few times so that I could earn the Speed Run achievement.+ Art - Crisp sprites and nice backgrounds.  Fun sound effects.  This 6 year old game feels like it could have been released today.+ Music - A calming soundtrack that doesn't get old or annoying as you figure out each level.  The music follows the same timeline as your character (e.g. turn back time and the music plays backwards; speed up time and the music speeds up) which is a great touch that helps with immersion.  The string-heavy soundtrack lends itself well to such temporal manipulations.+ Level design - Every level feels fresh and interesting.  Some levels are repeated across worlds, but adapated slightly to the unique mechanic of each world.  You might get frustrated once or twice, but every puzzle has a clean and fair solution.+ Length - Braid feels like the perfect length.  It took me about four hours to complete the first time around and I was satisfied by the depth to which the various mechanics were explored.  It's a nice, bite-sized game.~ Story - Told through a few short bits of text, the story is not at the forefront of this game.  There is likely symbolism that ties the mechanics of the game to the story, but it isn't really made obvious to the player.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page.Gameplay: For the most part this review is going to be something of a retrospective,  as most anyone reading this will already know what Braid's gameplay entails. If you don't, however, here's a brief explanation: this game is a puzzle-platformer in which you can reverse time, and use various gimmicks in tandem with the time control in order to solve puzzles. Your controls are (on the 360 controller) analog stick/D-Pad to move, A to Jump, X to reverse time, and that's pretty much it until World 6 in which they add another gimmick.Now for the retrospective: this is one of the many games that I never actually got around to playing when it was new, so I'm able to go into the game without any presumptions of the quality of the game. Basically, this review is for those who are wondering how well the game holds up to this day. I can confidently say that, given the deluge of puzzle platformers spurred on by games like this, that this game holds up quite well. There weren't really any dumb puzzles that required an obscene amount of platforming precision, the difficulty curve of the puzzles was good enough to make the solution not always obvious, but never so obscure that it gets frustrating, and the puzzle pieces within the stages were all pretty fun to get. One thing that may be a bit bothersome is that the game does expect you to find out the mechanics of the gimmicks for yourself, which I know is annoying for some people playing the game (for example, you can boost enemies upwards by jumping into them from beneath, but the game never tells you about this and it is required for 100%), but I never had too much of an issue with it.To be honest, the most disappointing thing about this game is its length: the game only took me three and a half hours to beat, and that was all in one sitting. I would have liked to have seen a level editor for this game, as I think there is quite a lot of room for elements of the various gimmicks to be explored. However, at the very least the game doesn't overstay its welcome, and after beating it I do feel somewhat satisfied with my time. For me, this wasn't exactly a puzzle game that blew my socks off, but it is a fun, simple, relaxing puzzle platformer, and for some that's all you really want. 8/10.Story: It's difficult to talk about this game's story, because there both is and isn't a story. There is a story in that there is a semi-coherent chain of events that you as  the protagonist go through, but at the same time there isn't, as there really is no conclusive ending. I will say that the last level of the game does serve as a surprisingly effective setpiece with which the game ends on, albeit not necessarily an ending. Still though, given the vague allusions throughout the game, the final level does come as something of a twist, and a fairly good one at that. There are various interpretations on the Internet for the actual circumstances of the plot, but going off of just what's in here, I'll give the game a 8/10 for a good, although short story.Graphics: I'll just get the technical stuff out of the way: if your computer doesn't run this game, I feel bad for you because you may actually be using my old garbage Dell Dimension E310 that could hardly run XP with an anti-virus installed. I'd recommend that when the game launches you change the screen size to your resolution, as leaving it on Auto puts it to 1280x720. Anyways, all that aside, the game is simply gorgeous. The environments never stop being beautiful, the sprites are very well animated, and there's just a lot of detail here. Excellent quality through and through on the graphics front. 5/5.Sound: The OST is very much inspired by classical music of the 16th/17th century, so if you're really into that sorta thing then you'll have a great time with the soundtrack. For me, the soundtrack provided a nice backdrop to the game itself, but I do find myself having a bit of a tough time remembering any of the songs from the game, even after having just played it. This may just be a thing with me, but nothing on the OST really stood out to me. Apart from that, there really isn't much else to talk about here. 3/5.Overall scores are: 8/8/5/3; cumulative score of 8.0/10. I'd say that this game still holds up quite well to this day; however, I don't necessarily think it's as amazing as some people are making it out to be. Then again, I may be an uncultured pleb or something i dunno

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												An ABSOLUTE masterpiece. This is a puzzle platformer with incredible artwork, a delightful soundtrack, and an amazing storyline. The puzzles are perfectly put together and are VERY well done and creative, I can't even begin to imagine how someone would come up with most of these puzzles. Throughout the game you're given different powers, whether they can slow down time in a specific region, or rewind the world, they are given to you at perfect points throughout your adventure to keep you interested, and are incorporated into each puzzle professionally. Braid was an absolute delight to play through, and there's no reason why it should ever not be recommended: I honestly cannot find any flaws in it's design. People that rate Braid bad probably aren't that good at puzzle games or got fed up with it. I know there were a few points where I felt like giving up because some puzzles aren't obvious in the slightest, but when comparing Braid to other games of the puzzle platformer genre, it is clearly the king. The storyline is told by text for the most part, and a few cinematic-like scenes. The ending is breathtaking, and I HIGHLY recommend Braid above even most triple-A production quality games. The sincerity and heart put into Braid is incredible, and you can feel it radiating with every step you take. I can't recommend Braid highly enough, I think it's an experience any gamer should partake in. The asking price of $9.99 is very fair, as Braid is lovingly crafted and has a very good playtime given it's genre. I don't give out many near-10's. Only about five so far and I've played hundreds of games. Braid deserves this score, as it's flawless and is up there in my top 10 games of all time, as well as being near the pinnacle of my favorite gaming experiences.9.8/10

												One of my favorite puzzle platformers. Very clever use of time. Levels are grouped together and each group of levels will introduce a new mechanic. Some levels require a lot of thinking. One of the few puzzler-based games that I would return to every few months to see if I could finally figure out levels I was stuck on. Perhaps the not very interesting story is a benefit as I am not tempted to search the Internet for solutions to challenging levels in order to progress the story. Clearing tough levels is very satisfying.When new mechanics are introduced, the game does a good job increasing the difficulty level to level, easing you along until you come across a brain teaser.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Braid ReviewBraid is the story of a guy named Tim. That is as much as I can remember from the story, seeing it had very little to do with the game.GAMEPLAY- As Tim you have the power to run, jump, climb, and control time. If you couldn’t tell the game heavily focuses on time control aspect. This sounds like a good mechanic for a game. In this case, the time puzzles come off are more annoying than they are fun. You can also rewind time faster and completely stop time, which you learn if you rewind enough. The pictures in the first level to show you how everything works and you eventually learn about time rewind power, once you die. Rewinding saves time for the gamer as opposed to going to a game over sign. Each world has its own mechanic, which is fun. The game lacks any connection to the story, because the story is told through reading books, you know that thing you wanted to do when playing a video game. Throughout the whole game there is only one battle, the battle is fun, but there is only one of them. I know that this game is mellower than others and I’m fine with mellow, but there should at least be one battle for each world. Lastly, the puzzle pieces are more important than they seem to be. They are look as if they were any other extra collectable in a platformer. You can still continue to the next world even if you do not collect all the pieces. Then after you complete world 6 you climb up the ladder only to find out you need the pieces. You may think “well maybe you get something or learn something to help you get the pieces”. Nope, you can every piece in a playthrough of a world. If you want to make the pieces seem more important, don’t let the player enter a new world without all the pieces.ATMOSPHERE- Music is good, the bunny sounds like a cat, but I didn’t play this game because of the realism, so sure why not. Graphics are amazing just due to the textures alone, though the colors are also well doneSTORY- There was a princess and she got kidnapped, Tim wants to rescue her. Not the most compelling plot in the world but it is what it is. There is more to the story but there was a lot of optional reading that I just didn’t care for. So good news is I cannot possibly spoil this game. I wasn’t confused about what was going on either, not until a dinosaur came out of castle at the end of the world, and said “Your princess is in another castle”. If I remember correctly from the story, a monster took the princess, and a dinosaur could be considered a monster. What he says is exactly what somebody who captured the princess would said, so in the end it was the dinosaur. Then again I didn’t play the last level, because I didn’t care to get all the pieces. CONCLUSION- In the end, this game could have been better if they added a few things. More battles, make the pieces more important, and make the story feel more important. If you want a platformer play Battleblock Theater or Super Meat Boy. If you want a puzzler play The Bridge. If you want a game about a guy named Tim, play Skyrim and call your guy Tim. This game feels like biting into a sandwich with nothing but lettuce.
